We are committed to building MEV-Share in the open and are looking for partners:
- Wallets: we'd love to understand your requirements
- Researchers: we have impactful open questions!
- Searchers: we'd love ideas for what data to share
- Builders: we'd love to collaborate on APIs
Check out Bert's thread, which goes into much more detail: https://t.co/rZ0mXAg5KO

MEV-Share heavily utilizes design primitives introduced in SUAVE, such as programmable privacy, preference expression, and credible commitments.

While this protocol only connects users and searchers today, it can be generalized to all parties in the MEV supply chain over time.

What sets MEV-Share apart from all other designs in the OFA market is that it is
- fully permissionless for searchers
- doesn't enshrine a single block builder
- offers programmable privacy for users
- and a credible roadmap toward decentralization

In MEV-Share, users control what information about their trades searchers can see before submitting backruns.

Selectively revealing transaction data can help searchers optimize their bids, which means higher payments back to the user.

When MEV-Share is live, users, applications, and wallets can send their transactions to a new RPC endpoint, where a "matchmaker" simulates their trades against independently created searcher backruns.

The resulting arbitrage profits are then kicked back to the user.

Just in time for Valentine's Day, Flashbots' product lead @bertcmiller unveiled a design document for our latest product: MEV-Share.

As the name implies, MEV-Share is a protocol for returning MEV back to the users who create it.

Finally, the Staking Router marks an important update in Lido's strategy:

From a staking pool to a staking platform where stakers and all kinds of Node Operators can come together in a free market.

All benefiting from the brand and network effect of the stETH token.

‚úÖ For Stakers, it means they benefit from a more diverse and secure Node Operator set.
‚úÖ For Ethereum, we are mitigating risk and further improving the decentralization of the staking layer.
‚úÖ For Node Operators, many of them can now participate in Lido for the first time.

The Staking Router is such a big deal, it's hard to overstate.

It means anyone will be able to make a new module for receiving user stake and putting it to work.

Solo staking and DVT are coming to Lido! https://t.co/KeOASQEEdW

Lido V2 features two big changes:

1. Withdrawals: Users can take stETH and withdraw ETH directly from the Beacon Chain.

2. The Staking Router: A new modular architecture that allows for adding and managing arbitrary new staking modules.

For years, the North Star on Lido's Road to Decentralization has been allowing Node Operators to join without permission.

idk if there‚Äôs a moral to the story, but I‚Äôve always struggled w healthy & effective Twitter usage, so it feels like a step forward personally.

I‚Äôd say it‚Äôs a composite of several effects:
1) getting a new yardstick against which to measure success
2) being more busy means being on Twitter has a real cost now
3) changing my peer group changed my frame. I stopped caring what CT thinks about me

I‚Äôve always been a very competitive person and the motivation behind a lot of my tweets was winning arguments, and maybe working through new topics by public debate. since joining Flashbots, I don‚Äôt feel like I need that anymore

the good = valuable and often obscure information, sentiment, networking, sharing posts/announcements
the bad = getting sucked into fights, emotional stress, hurting others, huge time sink

spending less time on Twitter has been one of the most positive changes for my life + productivity in the past year. I think I found a better way for myself to get most of the good out of Twitter while avoiding more of the bad

MEV is the study of some actors being more powerful than others, the direct and indirect costs of abusing this power, and how we can improve the fairness of our systems.

By the way, Bitcoin itself has an optimistic security model as well! 

We optimistically assume that a longer chain doesn‚Äôt exist because 1) we don‚Äôt see one 2) it‚Äôs costly. 

With every block built on top, we update the probability. But in theory, the challenge period is endless

Because of these incentives, you gain more settlement assurance with every block where a fraud proof *doesn‚Äôt happen*.

For all practical purposes, you have the equivalent of 1-2 Bitcoin confirmations after the first 1-2 Ethereum blocks.

I think you have some more reading to do ü§î

The challenge period may be one week but that doesn‚Äôt mean it takes a week for the batch to finalize. 

*If* a batch is fraudulent otherwise faulty, it can be challenged immediately, and there‚Äôs a financial incentive for doing so.

6) I've seen the damaging effects of gambling. as a former professional poker player, prob more than almost any of you. I am not proud of it in hindsight but it's a part of my history.

7) seeing the two merge gives me the absolute creeps
4) But what this typically ignores is the opportunity cost: how many friends, skills, etc. would I have developed spending the same 20k hrs doing something else?
3) I have clearly benefited from them (learned better English, made new friends, developed strategic thinking, etc.). this part is 100% true for me
2) I can _hardly remember a single hour_ of those. it's all a blur, no long-term memories created. I bet you that no one, on their deathbed, will wish they had played more video games
1) I've been addicted to gaming for a long time with prob 10-20k hrs total just in my top games. I have even worse cases among friends of mine, some of which I'd now consider lost to addiction
and finally, where am I coming from and why does this bother me at all?

scientific evidence has shown that games (in moderation) can be good but the fact of the matter is that this research looked at a different generation of games and doesn't apply today.

I'm sure that my position will eventually become evidence supported if it's not already.

I also know that most games *in absolute numbers* are not like that. but most of the *game-hours* are logged into games that are. 

did you know that the mobile gaming market is now 4-5x the size of the PC gaming market?

as a result, the formerly separate fields of gaming and gambling have started to merge. 

this would be bad but acceptable if it weren't for the fact that these games are actively targeting kids/adolescents.

many of the most popular games today have a single goal: 

to addict the player as much as possible in an endless dopamine-driven compulsion loop to get them to spend money inside the game.

if you experienced games before they became crack, you can feel fortunate

I could say a lot of things but will prob limit it to one:

many people seem to think of the solo-player adventure/strategy/education type of games *they* played growing up, which may or may not have been a long time ago.

but modern games are *mostly* not like that anymore

Over the coming weeks, we will release technical specs and posts that will provide more color on the different milestones on our roadmap, and how we can get there together.

Join the forum discussion: https://t.co/b0tzTs8VmQ

To enable maximum coopetion, we are building SUAVE in the open and invite all interested parties ‚Äî users, wallets, searchers, builders, researchers, and blockchain developers ‚Äî to work with us.
https://t.co/zH4fUI6Dge

MEV is the Millennium Prize Problem of crypto. We are convinced that the value to be unlocked through coopetition in MEV is monumental. We believe that the sum is greater than its parts and that we can align the best possible execution with the most decentralized infrastructure.

We must make sure block building as a process ends up meaningfully decentralized in power, because crypto must end up decentralized, and because humanity needs decentralization in its financial systems, now more than ever.

Two years ago, to this day, we announced our mission to mitigate the negative externalities and existential risks posed by MEV to smart-contract blockchains.

Today, we are taking the next step.
https://t.co/ay1bTWkNZp

Read the post for a roadmap of our planned milestones:

üí´ SUAVE Centauri
üåÉ SUAVE Andromeda
‚òÄÔ∏è SUAVE Helios

https://t.co/zH4fUI6Dge

@bertcmiller has a great thread to dive further into the design principles behind SUAVE:

https://t.co/fvr5UltoRs

‚öíÔ∏è Decentralized Block Building:

A decentralized network for and of block builders to access the encrypted preferences from users and merge them into partial or full blocks.

üí™ Optimal Execution Market:

A network of special parties called executors who listen to the SUAVE mempool and compete to provide the best execution for user preferences.

üí¨ Universal Preference Environment:

A chain and mempool specialized for preference expression and settlement to surface and aggregate the preferences from users and searchers from all participating chains in a single place.

So what is SUAVE? At its core, a single environment where parties can collaborate on the expression, execution, and settlement of preferences.

It is composed of three components:
1. Universal Preference Environment
2. Optimal Execution Market
3. Decentralized Block Building https://t.co/1YYK5iEeOt

SUAVE also presents a major opportunity:

Sharing the same sequencing layer allows block builders to capture cross-domain MEV, validators to maximize their revenue, and users to transact with the best execution, while reducing the economic centralization pressure on each domain. https://t.co/nPzBK6J100
There are many reasons why we think the market will evolve toward many chains sharing a single decentralized sequencing layer: https://t.co/CJwnFqXAne
Importantly, SUAVE goes beyond sequencing for a single blockchain. We designed SUAVE to be the mempool and block builder for all blockchains. https://t.co/l0Xgauvmnx
SUAVE unbundles the mempool and block builder role from existing blockchains and offers a specialized and decentralized plug-and-play alternative. https://t.co/jEn8Is2kFG

At DevCon 2022, @phildaian unveiled our vision for SUAVE - the Single Unifying Auction for Value Expression.

Today, we are giving you the full picture.
https://t.co/l3nXvNY71n

Scale economies from exclusive orderflow and cross-domain MEV suggest that a diversity of builders is not guaranteed and a small number of builders may emerge dominant.

We must make sure to keep MEV decentralized, or the decentralization of crypto will be lost.

Right now, we are here: Over the last 30 days, 5 block builders were responsible for >80% of Ethereum blocks.

The effects can be felt today in builders asserting their own legal + risk preferences on production, but this is just a symptom or a bigger issue.

We are excited to make our biggest announcement to date.

After successfully isolating the centralizing effects of MEV to the block builder role, we are turning toward a new challenge:

To decentralize block building itself.

https://t.co/zH4fUI6Dge

3. the chance that a major stablecoin will honor redemptions on this fork over eth2 is not 5%, its not 1%, its a cold zero. anyone who says otherwise is a grifter.
2. a lot of hashpower does not give this chain any significant value.

MKR holders still have to ratify any spell and can fire council members at any time. Therefore, control always remains with MKR holders, while division of labor and specialization are unlocked.

If you want to read more, come check out the full thread: https://t.co/2v0ThuEvHw

With a Council, the chart further evolves to look like this: Strategy is now firmly the job of the Council, which is itself held accountable by MKR holders, delegates, and the constitution itself. https://t.co/J6tSjWZtpA

The second change is the introduction of a Council of Makers. This breaks out the second part of the supply chain, which is Strategy. The Council's job is to set a high-level strategy that implements the vision laid out in the constitution, and manage the budget. https://t.co/FEVNpS6zSN

With a constitution, the above chart would look more like this: The vision is now put in stone via the constitution and removed from the everyday decision process -- many decisions can even be derived from it automatically. Further, there's a clear process for updating it. https://t.co/bUhzxKg4i4

The proposal introduces two key changes. The first is a written constitution for Maker. The constitution breaks out Maker's vision and allows it to be debated individually. More importantly, it encodes in writing what cannot be encoded in smart contract code. https://t.co/dcyBKO87np

Maker's governance supply chain is looking like this: CUs handle the low-level implementation, while all other choices are kicked to MKR holders. These holders often have to decide on imperfect information, without a long-term plan, and without a holistic view of Maker. https://t.co/xh0fceIXGN
Maker lacks a coherent vision, leading the constant discussion around the following battle lines: https://t.co/lnlFAk2Mhn

At the core of every organization is what I call the "governance supply chain". Most organizations start with flat hierarchies but eventually run into the scaling limits of that approach. Hierarchy is introduced to unlock specialization, division of labor, and accountability. https://t.co/VqtmasN7in

I just proposed a series of simple governance changes to @MakerDAO that would address many problems that exist in governance today. These include a general lack of vision and strategy as well as low accountability to MKR holders.

In Bancor's case, the death spiral goes like this:
1) external shock causes IL => more BNT is printed
2) in expectation of supply inflation, market sells off BNT
3) more IL => more BNT printing => more selling => more IL => more BNT printing, etc.

Remember -- the way that AMMs work is that if you hold assets A + B in an LP, and A goes to zero, the AMM will sell all of B on the way down until the LP is stuck with 100% A -- and a full loss of capital on their hands.

Bancor was actually a much bigger scam than I think anyone anticipated. In return for protection from IL, LPs anchor themselves 100% to the value of BNT. But BNT, and all of their deposits, can go to zero in days.

Our proposal combines both strategies into a new mechanism that we call LDO+stETH dual governance. An execution delay is added, and stETH holders receive the ability to veto any decisions that LDO holders make. https://t.co/QdyoxzLNRd
An example of improving information flow is the addition of long timelocks before governance decisions get executed. This would allow stakers plenty of time to withdraw if they ever disagree.

While our efforts to ossify Lido are ongoing, we turn our focus to the second point - solving the principal-agent problem. 

In general, there are two classes of solutions:
1) improving the flow of information
2) aligning the incentives between agent and principal

To address this problem, we're using a dual-pronged strategy:
1)  Reduce the scope of governance (-> what can go wrong) as much as possible via ossification
2) For the remaining decisions, solve the principal-agent problem between LDO holders and stakers

At the root of this problem is a principal-agent problem:

By choosing to stake with Lido, stakers (the principal) authorize LDO holders (the agent) to manage their stake on their behalf.

The risk is that the agent acts in a way that is not in the principal's best interest.

We're starting from the following problem statement: 

Lido protocol is governed by the LDO token and this carries certain risks for stakers and by extension Ethereum itself. https://t.co/XTRZB7EeVz

Excited to co-author what I see as a revolutionary proposal for @LidoFinance and Defi in general: our "LDO+stETH dual governance" system addresses the principal-agent problem between stakers and LDO holders by giving veto power to stETH holders.

@ChainLinkGod Another fact that you might appreciate is that miners in PoW don't know what block they are working on either - only the pool operator does. The workers are just hashing away at the hashed block header they receive from the pool operator. So the same dynamic exists today.

@ChainLinkGod point being, neither miners nor stakers are there to check the validity of a block. Their role is to give economic weight to a single fork of the blockchain, thereby collapsing the wave function of the infinite number of possible forks, and creating consensus.

@ChainLinkGod If we map this to PoW, miners actually don't even check the validity of the block they mine on because there's no reason to ever expect another miner to send you an invalid block with a valid PoW. There have been some interesting stale blocks because of that in the past

Lastly, there are risks we need to stay vigilant of.

While Stage 3 PBS will solve the need for mutually trusted relays, builder centralization can be a bigger issue in the future. mev-boost is taking an important step by making competition between builders as easy as possible. https://t.co/t0j0fLbEiz

A final benefit is that mev-boost addresses a problem that all staking pools like Lido, Rocketpool, Alluvial, etc., have: their node operators are incentivized to hide the true value of blocks from the user!

mev-boost is an oracle for how much blocks are actually worth. https://t.co/gADNSZZvN3

While the goal is to move to Stage 3 PBS, there are good reasons to move ahead with an out-of-protocol solution for now. 

mev-boost is an important interim step that allows us to gather data and iterate toward the winning design before enshrining it in Ethereum itself. https://t.co/lYFk5AVlIO
In terms of security, mev-boost is designed from the ground up for maximum security and redundancy. This matters to Ethereum but also to participating validators. https://t.co/GGwBiYD8BL
Unlike Stage 1 PBS where all participating miners had to run mev-geth, mev-boost will also work with any client. This supports Ethereum's goal of increased client diversity. https://t.co/5U9IBWsDEK

But I think the most underrated aspect of mev-boost is that it is completely neutral infrastructure.

While not everyone was agreeing with Flashbots' mev-auction approach, builders in mev-boost can use any ordering approach they want, and we expect users to vote with their feet. https://t.co/WqdTYgSoXd

Going from a 1-to-many builder world can also increase Ethereum's censorship resistance. 

Finally, we expect some builders to compete on features like account abstraction, privacy, paying MEV back to users, and more! https://t.co/sHnblYNI2K

mev-boost, which can be seen as Stage 2 PBS, is good for many reasons.

An open market between builders maximizes revenue for validators. 

But mev-boost will especially help solo validators, who were too small to participate in Stage 1 PBS. https://t.co/VxWxKrDcAw
This technique is called proposer-builder-separation and is rolled out to Ethereum in three stages: https://t.co/lnu1pDZ5MU

Block production consists of (1) building the best block from all available transactions, and (2) proposing this block to the network. The increasing difficulty of block building due to MEV is a centralizing force in Ethereum and the solution is to separate the two roles cleanly.

As MEV is becoming even more important in PoS Ethereum, Flashbots is about to release mev-boost, a neutral middleware that allows any builder to openly compete in making the best blocks. This is great for validators, staking pools, and Ethereum itself.
https://t.co/EN8Ma4pqLr

Can you track an ‚ÄûESG bitcoin‚Äú? The answer is nuanced (thread)

@AviFelman in your example, you know the miner who made the block that a coin was created in. but that‚Äòs a pretty arbitrary definition. most of the work spent on securing a coin will be expended later - by other miners who work on top of it. 

that‚Äòs the cumulative security of PoW
@AviFelman every block builds on top of the previous blocks and makes them harder to replace. so in a sense, miners keep ‚Äûproducing‚Äú more security for the same coins.

@AviFelman by the way, there is another nuance to your bet - it depends what you define as ‚Äûproduced a bitcoin‚Äú.

miners don‚Äòt mine bitcoin - they mine blocks. in return, they get paid in bitcoin, some from inflation and some from fees.

@AviFelman so takeaways:

1) a wallet that receives 1 ‚Äûclean‚Äú BTC can always isolate and send that 1 BTC further

2) can either be done by the user or built into the wallet‚Äòs UTXO management

3) later transactions can split or merge a UTXO, making it harder to track

@AviFelman UTXOs always have to be spent as a whole, so sometimes new UTXOs are created, e.g.:

10 BTC (in your wallet) -> 8 BTC (go to receiver) + 2 BTC (change for the sender)

UTXOs can also be merged, e.g.:

2 BTC + 2 BTC (in your wallet) -> 4 BTC (go to receiver)

@AviFelman what we know as ‚Äûbitcoin‚Äú exists in the form of ‚Äûunspent transaction outputs‚Äú (UTXOs). transactions take these as inputs, destroy them, and recreate new outputs controlled by a different signature.
Many such cases unfortunately.

@DegenSpartan @DRotholz @gakonst if you include my counterarguments alongside your arguments, we have no problem ü§ù

anyone who starts staking from here is better off buying stETH on secondary market rather than staking ETH directly

before stETH supply can expand again, stETH/ETH price will have returned to 1

without any incentives etc. from Lido

another important takeaway is that anyone buying or holding stETH at a discount today doesn‚Äòt need to wait for redemptions before the exchange rate will return to 1

the other (far more likely condition) is that demand for staking will go up

in this second case, new stakers are always better off first buying the discounted stETH on the market before staking directly (tax reasons notwithstanding)

Lido actively encourages stakers to do so

to summarize:

when stETH > ETH demand: staked ETH goes up, stETH/ETH at 1

when stETH < ETH demand: staked ETH stays constant, stETH/ETH goes down

creating more stETH from ETH is possible, and so the exchange rate will always be arbitraged down to 1. 

the increased demand will reflect in the supply of stETH (not its price!) instead.

in the other direction, this is not possible, since unstaking is not yet supported

the market/investor sentiment determines whether the NET carry of stETH vs ETH is positive or negative.

when it‚Äòs positive, more people want to create stETH from ETH (start staking)

when it‚Äòs negative, more people want to redeem stETH for ETH (unstake)

stETH has some negative carry (as discussed below) but importantly it has positive carry as well! 

the positive carry is the yield that stETH accrues compared to ETH. 

for example, after one year, 1 stETH will be 1.07 stETH whereas 1 ETH is still 1 ETH.

üí≠ Finally, what is a risk to some people can be a big opportunity for everyone else.

Anyone can buy stETH at a discount, e.g. 0.98 ETH, and redeem it for 1.00 ETH once withdrawals are available. Risk-free.

This is on top of staking rewards, LDO incentives, and soon fees+MEV.

üí≠ Don't become a forced seller into an already falling market.

If you use leverage:

1) Use safe LTV ratio that can withstand big market swings!
2) Always monitor your current LTV ratio and react accordingly!
3) Use auto-deleveraging tools like @DeFiSaver!

üí≠ Note for leveraged stakers

Depending on the size of your leverage, a falling stETH price in secondary markets can reduce the value of your principal (stETH) compared to the value of your loan (ETH).

If this ratio (called LTV) falls enough, you are at risk of liquidation.

üí≠Who *is* affected by stETH secondary market price?

For one, anyone looking to sell their stETH before the primary market opens. 

‚ÄºÔ∏è But primarily, anyone who uses their stETH as collateral to get leverage (e.g. to stake more ETH and juice their returns)

üí≠Who is unaffected by stETH secondary market price? (hint: almost everyone)

The price of stETH in secondary markets has no effect on its value in the primary market.

As a longer-term staker of ETH, you can always redeem 1 stETH for 1 ETH in the future.

üí≠Who is unaffected by stETH secondary market price? (hint: almost everyone)

So, stETH is a claim on 1 ETH in the primary market, but these claims can be traded as well. 

These are the secondary stETH markets.

(btw, that's why we call stETH a staking "derivative")

üí≠First, what actually is stETH?

1 stETH is a claim on 1 staked ETH on the Ethereum Beacon chain. 

You can redeem it after withdrawals from the BC are enabled, which is planned for EOY 2022.

This is the primary stETH market.

Some projects can get away by ‚Äûdefecting‚Äú in this prisoner‚Äòs dilemma and creating a social rule that honorary owner can never sell. But it‚Äòs the same logic that projects use that tease a future airdrop, get people to investment liquidity, and then never pay up.

If honoraries could never be sold, there‚Äòd be no reward and hence no incentive to ever receive it.

This would be pull the rug under the *concept* of honoraries, leading the worse publicity and marketing and ultimately community overall.

But the core of it, receiving an honorary and showcasing it is still a risk for the receiver. That‚Äòs why many people are extremely picky about the ones they accept in the first place.

That risk must be compensated.

Some honorary owners might decide to never sell the same way that many investors (esp those managing only their own money) never sell particular companies until they die. 

In NFTs, this effect will probably 100x stronger because the token is non-fungible and deeply personal.

All NFT projects are better off long-term if honoraries can be sold

There are a lot of parallels between honoraries and like angel tickets - the receiver stakes their reputation on a particular project for a share in the collection.

The second channel was only used so E wouldn't get suspicious and tip-off A that something foul was going on. Both got tricked.

Or so you think! 

What actually happened was that B made *two* channels, one with A where they controlled B and E. And one with E where they controlled A and B.

So in the first channel, B pretended to be E and sent their own address, A sent the funds, and B ran away. https://t.co/N46R42V0II

In this case, we also have these parties
- my friend (A)
- his counterparty (B)
- an escrow (E)

After the terms had been agreed on, B made a Telegram channel with A and E. Then E posted the deposit address into the channel, A sent a test which E confirmed, then A sent the rest.

The typical workflow in an OTC trade is that you have two parties, A and B, who want to trade with each other but neither wants to send first. So they both send their funds to third-party escrow E, who will send A's funds to B and vice versa.
Yesterday a friend of mine got scammed for a pretty substantial amount in an OTC trade on Telegram. I had not seen this method before and thought others should be aware of it:

@sternesiech @fnietom @Truthcoin @peterktodd You don‚Äòt have to trust others in a blockspace cartel, because you cannot produce and hoard/sell blockspace offline. The only market that exists for it is in the Bitcoin network.
@fnietom @sternesiech @Truthcoin @peterktodd The target blocksize/min fee rate could be fed to the miners via the cartel oracle that simulates the optimal supply/ask price.

@fnietom @sternesiech @Truthcoin @peterktodd A non-conforming block would be one that 
1) is above a certain size
2) accepts txns below a certain fee rate

Both rules can be enforced by an MASF at the protocol layer and violating blocks would simply be rejected/reorged.

@azakmay Bitcoin would stay around but there‚Äòd be a fork, let‚Äòs call it ‚ÄûBitcoin Secure‚Äú, that has inflation and much much faster confirmation times and no reorgs. Would many people and businesses use that over the existing Bitcoin? Most likely.

@sternesiech @fnietom @Truthcoin @peterktodd Such a cartel is undesirable because it establishes high coordination between miners and itself becomes a chokepoint for actors like the USG, so it stands to reason that the resulting system would no longer be Bitcoin. Proponents of this seem to expect a kind of ‚Äûfree lunch‚Äú that in my view doesn‚Äòt really exist. Your tokens only earn a yield if someone borrows them, which dilutes the supply as much as selling it.

This is definitely true and could be counted as an asset to the protocol itself. But counting it also raises some further questions:

a) Could a maintainer company be banned from continuing work on the protocol? If yes, what happens then?

2) Should we count maintainer company balance sheets, and if yes, how?

To give an example, we said that Uniswap‚Äòs treasury is empty. But in practice, it is maintained by Uniswap Labs, which has raised several rounds of capital and might have years of runway left.

Gnosis even has a huge treasury ($750m+) but at this size I would rather give that as an example of a product DAO that accidentally slipped into the investment DAO mindset - something we explicitly caution against in the article.

It is hence of much higher important that product DAOs manage their treasury well!

That said, there are some projects that fall into the product DAO category that deserve a shoutout: Keeper, Yearn, Synthetix, and Badger DAOs all have above-average treasuries.

I don‚Äòt mean that in negative way - you just cannot compare an investment DAO to a product DAO. If dxDAO disappeared tomorrow, no one except their investors would notice. 

But if Maker + Dai disappeared, tens if not hundreds of thousands of users would be affected.

1) The one on most people‚Äòs mind: Why didn‚Äòt we mention projects like Ohm, BitDAO, NounsDAO etc.? 

Simple, we were writing about projects that use a treasury + token as a tool to build a product for users, not projects where the treasury + token is the product.

It‚Äòs been two days since the release of our treasury guide and from what we can see it has sparked discussions in many channels, exactly what we were hoping for.

In this thread, I want to respond to some of the main discussion points that have come up:

@profjasonpotts You can absolutely put a financial value on treasury shares (we say that in the article) but it doesn‚Äòt eliminate the fact that bad events as well as predictable bear markets would force you to buy cash at a really high cost of capital if you don‚Äòt diversify.
@tokenterminal @MonetSupply Oh, we counted Compound‚Äòs market reserves as part of the treasury in our article

@MartyBent It's a good example of a self-fulfilling prophecy. If users agree Bitcoin doesn't have a security problem and use it over alternatives, you indeed get higher demand + utility and consequently, the odds of the security problem materializing are much smaller

@0xailes Yeah, certainly not from one tweet. I thought she was making a good point anyway that crypto people are financially incentivized to meme inflation into existence (i.e. getting others to sell USD). That line of thinking isn't novel, see e.g. Pierre Rochard's "speculative attack"

I'm not saying we shouldn't talk about the possibility of runaway inflation - not even that we should talk more about Bitcoin's potential security problem. Just that both are path-dependent and our decisions to talk about them affect their likelihood of happening.

It doesn't matter what you think, if others are selling, you should sell first because there is no price floor. But it's not like people in crypto are not aware of that. That's why the thought police come knocking whenever someone brings up Bitcoin's long-term security model.

Crypto people are making fun of this journalist for saying that summoning hyperinflation makes it more likely to appear. But she is undoubtedly correct, all markets and especially the market for money are Keynesian beauty contests.

We would love to see NFT developers start experimenting with these ideas, leading to a better variety of launches in the wild. 

A huge shoutout to those who have been sharing their tools and advice with the NFT community already:

"Do as I do, not as I say":

We also provide MultiRaffle, a reference implementation that we consider a good balance between all properties and that is simple to understand and build upon!
 
https://t.co/Ce2fXQOFQ7

Using a methodical approach, we break down each phase (bidding, clearing, distribution, and metadata reveal). We explain what options developers have, and how their choices affect the design goals of their launch.

For example, in the highly common FCFS fixed-price sale, users submit bids to miners, who are tasked with clearing them every block.

Turning this continuous process into a sequential one (e.g. a raffle or batched auction) leads to much better outcomes.

But how can we do better?
 
At the center is our realization that *every* NFT launch consists of the same four steps:
 
1) Bidding: Users submit bids
2) Clearing: Winners are determined
3) Distribution: Winners receive NFTs
4) Metadata reveal: Properties of NFTs are revealed

From looking at the damage from bad launch designs, we derive six desirable properties of an NFT launch:
 
üé≤ Unexploitable fairness
üèéÔ∏è No race conditions
üåç Time-zone agnostic
‚õΩÔ∏è Gas-efficient
ü§ù Inclusive
üëÆ Trustless

A second example is first-come-first-served (FCFS) sales with a fixed price. 

Last month's Times NFT launch sold out in less than three minutes, excluding regular users completely. Worse, we found that 10,962 users lost 252 ETH ($800k!) across 12,743 reverted transactions.

We start by highlighting anti-patterns in NFT-land that have been harming users in the wild.

For example, "More Loot" used transparent metadata. This allowed savvy users to rank items by scarcity before minting them and snipe only the rarest ones.

(x: time, y: scarcity) https://t.co/DbTF5vh1ON

All NFT launches face similar challenges (e.g. pricing, randomness, gas-efficiency...), causing design patterns to emerge.

An anti-pattern is a common response to a problem that is ineffective or even counter-productive.

Sometimes recourse is impossible because parties are anonymous, but that shouldn't be confused with thinking that seeking recourse is bad *in general*.

Redundancy creates trust.

This layered approach is a strength, not a weakness. 

It is only just that when a smart contract fails, you can (and should) still appeal to any other institutions you can.

All institutions exist in stack. When one fails, you appeal to the next.

When a market fails (e.g. because you got scammed), you appeal to a court.

If the court fails (e.g. delivers bad judgment), you appeal to a higher court.

Blockchains are global trust machines, allowing us to rely on existing institutions less often.

They are already the cheapest way to establish trust in many economic interactions today.

Reducing the cost of trust is THE single biggest reason why crypto is revolutionary.

But existing institutions can be faulty, expensive, unfair, or too local (how do you establish trust between someone in the US and China?)

This is where blockchains and smart contracts come in.

Economic interactions are only possible when trust between parties can be established.

So humans create institutions like moral codes/religion, a monopoly on violence, the legal system, markets, money, etc. to establish trust between participants and lower transaction costs.

I don't really share the view "the outcome of a smart contract is law/code is law"

Smart contracts don't replace basic moral behavior or the traditional legal system, and that's okay:

(a thread on the most important concept in cryptoüí°) https://t.co/i2clDa32FN

Summary: I posited that EIP-1559 effectively batches many txns, breaking the way searchers used to express ordering preferences in a PGA. Do you agree/disagree? Share your thoughts

So bundles will always be invented, only question is they are invented as a private/proprietary sidechannel between some searchers/miners or globally available for all. So IMO futile to long for a pre-bundle world.

c) We naively assumed that there are no bundles, but this thread shows by both searchers and miners 
*want* this txn type to exist. When they can communicate exact ordering preferences, the total value of the block goes up, at the expense of the users.

b) If it‚Äòs first-seen, backrunning changes from a bidding war to a latency war. Think a seeing a 1 gwei txn and then immediately sending the miner your own 1 gwei txn as well. So backrunning MEV only changes but isn‚Äòt removed.

However: 
a) It depends on how miners group their txns. Standard used to be by gas price, but what breaks the tie between same price txns? Can either be randomized or first-seen.
4. If the above were true (and remember only PGAs no bundles), then EIP-1559 would effectively lead to batch settlement instead of ordering by gas price which makes front/backrunning harder.

3. as a front/backrunner, how do you communicate your target position to miners? Using less gwei would put you behind the entire batch (bad case) or even out of the block entirely (worst case). Using more gwei would put you ahead of the entire batch (bad case)

One for my MEV friends: I always said that EIP-1559 has no impact on MEV, but is that true? Assume we are still in PGA world and no bundles

2. miners tend to group same-fee txns

PoS - as many other drawbacks as it has - does not suffer from this incentive problem. Based on what we know today, stakers have a very high CAPEX ratio, hence are very "long" the native coin. (as you would guess)

If you simulated Ethereum's current situation, where miners have only few ETH left to mine before the end of PoW, the result will be lower alignment with the honest strategy, and more susceptibility to bribes.

The intuition - that we then proved with our model - was that the more "long" the native coin miners are, the more they are incentivized to follow the honest strategy, and the larger an external incentive/bribe/threat needs to be to subvert them.
In my paper with @_prestwich and @bcmakes, we used a hardware depreciation schedule and miners' CAPEX/OPEX ratio to calculate their balance sheet, i.e. how many BTC they have at stake.

Q: Will legacy txns also burn the basefee?

@st0rm_ninja Yw

Block weight: The weight that previously came from the PoW now comes from an attestation game that happens after the proposal. One miner proposes -> others attest to it -> giving the block weight.

So we‚Äòre still going through the same motions, just in a slightly diff way.

In Ethereum‚Äòs PoS implementation, miners are no longer doing any proof of work, so need a different solution:

Leader lottery: The leader is still chosen at random, but by a commit-reveal scheme to generate secure randomness called RANDAO

While this may sound complicated, it is actually very similar to Nakamoto Consensus. As a reminder:

1. A random leader is chosen
2. The leader proposes a block
3. The leader seals the block with a proof, giving it weight in the fork choice rule

@fleupold_ @BalancerLabs Yup they are the same, but iirc Bentobox was announced a couple months before Balancer‚Äòs vault

I think I am very happy w/ that choice. It allows Sushi to selectively add in-house innovations (Bentobox, Tines router) and otherwise focus on the areas where they are unrivaled in the DEX space, which is community/brand/biz-dev.

A few days ago I questioned whether Sushiswap should even try to build their own swap technology w/o a strong research partner, or rather license an existing solution. They chose the third option I didn‚Äòt see, which is to reimplement them instead.

I first thought Sushi was simply introducing three new static curves, but instead they copied the other big AMMs w/o forking them (at least in Uni‚Äòs case to respect the license)

And they are bundling these new pools with Bentobox and a new router (which are Sushi innovations)

Okay, after reading the post, it turns out that the three new pool types are actually reimplementations of
1) Uniswap v3 (concentrated liquidity)
2) Curve v1 (I think - they say based on stableswap invariant, and no oracle used)
3) Balancer v2 (weighted pools)
And here is the post, reading now https://t.co/8WdXnOr0tS
I must have missed the part about LPs providing the same capital to multiple pools at once, but sounds interesting. This is one of the innovations made possible by Bentobox + virtual AMM.
Overall the talk was very light on details on the actual curves used. Hoping for a followup post soon.

3) some mix between xy=k but a bit more concentrated and gas-efficient
- Up to 32 assets per pool, weighting possible (basically like Balancer)
- new factory allowing more pool types to be added in the future

Summary:
- new AMMs will be inside Bentobox, where idle assets can be used by yield farming strategies. No surprise there
- 3 new pool types.
1) concentrated liquidity
2) ‚Äûhybrid‚Äú which Joe said is for stablecoins.. bit confusing, expected this for the previous type

The two obvious options are, 
1) partner with someone who can help you a lot with research and implementation of new AMMs mechanics like Uniswap+Paradigm
2) license an existing solution like Uniswap v3 or Curve v2 so you can focus even more on your strengths

Sushi is innovating here with Bentobox, but so far the actual AMMs are not integrated and hence don't benefit from increased capital efficiency. So if you're spending money on partners, I would make sure that this critical area is covered.

If I had to guess, Sushi's biggest risk is falling behind on the actual AMM mechanics. xy=k is under attack from all sides. CLOB on L2/faster L1s, RFQ, batched auctions, and finally AMM/CLOB hybrids like Uniswap v3.

2) The debate on what strategic partners can do to help Sushi is very interesting but feels like putting the cart before the horse. I'd love to see more discussion of what areas Sushi actually needs help in the most.

Two notes on the Sushi sale: 
1) If there's a lockup + vesting schedule, there should obviously be a discount as well. Otherwise, the funds would be strictly better off buying spot (and idd many are owners already).

Thread: How to think about gov tokens? / Whether your protocol should launch one
@safetyth1rd Did you read the article? The team is not untransparent at all, many respected faces and day1 supporters of Defi

@AndreCronjeTech @eric_ruleman @safetyth1rd @JacksonPhallock @kaiynne So I would say, it‚Äòs not at all black and white. There are good reasons to go public early, and good reasons to stay private longer. It always depends on the specific needs of the individual project.

FIN

@AndreCronjeTech @eric_ruleman @safetyth1rd @JacksonPhallock @kaiynne - introduces lots of distractions for your product/tech team
- creates bad incentives to please the market/community in the short-term instead of ignoring them and building for the long-term

@AndreCronjeTech @eric_ruleman @safetyth1rd @JacksonPhallock @kaiynne These are the main pros, and there are just about as many cons I would say. 

Going public early:
- dilutes your ownership for capital/liquidity you may not even need
- introduces legal risk
- can create a community of braindead pumpers instead of genuine techn. supporters

@AndreCronjeTech @eric_ruleman @safetyth1rd @JacksonPhallock @kaiynne - Do you need access to cheap capital + organic marketing moreso than other value-adds? Then it can make sense to raise from the public instead of professional VC firms

@AndreCronjeTech @eric_ruleman @safetyth1rd @JacksonPhallock @kaiynne - Do you compete in a market with strong network effects? A token can help bootstrap that via liquidity mining incentives
- Do you compete in a market where price actions drives the (social) media cycle and keeps your project constantly in the news for free?

@AndreCronjeTech @eric_ruleman @safetyth1rd @JacksonPhallock @kaiynne 3) Whether you actually want to go public early depends is not a no-brainer but can depend on a few factors
- Does your protocol need governance? Then giving up control can *remove* risk (esp legal) instead of adding it

@AndreCronjeTech @eric_ruleman @safetyth1rd @JacksonPhallock @kaiynne 2) The moment you issue your token on a public blockchain (what most ppl care about) is the equivalent of ‚Äûgoing public‚Äú in traditional markets. So you can think of crypto protocols/companies going public much sooner, sometimes on day 1.

@AndreCronjeTech @eric_ruleman @safetyth1rd @JacksonPhallock @kaiynne I would add that I have (slightly) updated my mental model once more since writing this article. 

1) Every protocol has a token in the sense that someone controls the ownership/assets, even before they are issued. Investing contracts sometimes sell these tokens years in advance

@ChainLinkGod No, absolutely not. If Liquidations were free, then you give away the entire value to miners. But if you restrict them to participants of a virtual mempool, then *you* as the protocol can receive the proceeds of that bidding war.

One of my favorite things about EIP-1559 is how many Bitcoiners who look at it for the first time shout "central planning!!"

Then comes the realization that Bitcoin's blockspace market has the exact same elements of central planning

@btcede @loomdart If you think neither minimum price nor maximum quantity should be constrained, then maybe you should start exploring Bitcoin Satoshi's Vision instead ;)

@btcede @loomdart Read my other tweets about why Bitcoin's transaction fee market isn't any more "free" than Ethereum's. The total revenue is always price * quantity. Each system constrains one of the two. This is necessary to limit the growth of the blockchain.
@btcede @loomdart Both models are a form of "central planning", and one isn't better than the other.

@btcede @loomdart If you compare Bitcoin and Ethereum, Bitcoin fixes the maximum blocksize and lets the price of blockspace float. Ethereum fixes the price of blockspace in a given block (* not even entirely true, since it only sets a floor) and lets the maximum blocksize float.
@btcede @loomdart I don't think you're seeing the full picture. Resource consumption (blockspace) must be constrained in all blockchains.

@gakonst Basically thisüëáüèª, I reacted strongly because I fear that we can only fight cartelization with social norms, and social norms have to be set early so they can develop and strengthen over time.

@edbwt @gakonst It‚Äòs actually not a solution, because the transactions eventually become visible on-chain. So you will always learn that someone else has been bidding against you and won, and then you can contact them and create an off-chain agreement

@tradebutwhy @PrestonPysh Okay, the answer is pretty simple. A chain must have a vibrant economic activity that leads to a lot of transaction fees. If these fees exceed the level of inflation paid to miners, the native token can be deflationary.

@gakonst I would add that we should design the block template market in a way that makes cartelization as hard as possible, but unfortunately I have no idea how. At the very least, we can set strong social norms and enforce social punishment e.g. ban cartellizing searchers from Flashbots

@gakonst As we see, cartelization among searchers is actually a *failure mode* for Flashbots and maybe even Ethereum itself. IMO it‚Äòs important we don‚Äòt praise it as positive-sum thinking, but as parasitic negative-sum thinking.
@tradebutwhy @PrestonPysh Question for whom?

@gakonst 3) searchers cartelizing (whether its via KeeperDAO or private channels) -> the quality of the bundles/templates goes down -> a strong incentive for miners to professionalize and extract themselves -> scenario 1, not 2. Flashbots will have failed

@gakonst 2) antithesis: create a highly competitive market for bundles (today) / block templates (in the future) -> ‚Äûdumb‚Äú miners can simply buy the best one and lose very little relative to ‚Äûsmart‚Äú miners who extract themselves. This is Flashbots

as a result, there is no reason to expect that if ETH/USD doubles in value, that gas/USD should double as well. this *can* happen temporarily because the same factor - e.g. a very bullish market - causes both, but one doesn't cause the other.

nowadays, many transactions are not even paid for in ETH at all, but various forms of off-chain payment. in fact, it's easiest to think about the market for gas (block space) as completely separate from the market of ETH/USD, with gas and ETH trading completely independently.

when people want to transact, they need to buy gas. gas prices are often quoted in gwei/gas. but note that this a free market - there's neither a floor nor ceiling for how much gas can clear, and so the clearing price of gas in gwei varies wildly.

in Ethereum, we price EVM computation and other key resources (bandwidth, storage) in the fictitious unit of "gas". currently, there are 15m of gas per block available. bitcoin works similarly, except we call it "block weight" there.
in this thread, Preston worries that if EIP-1559 raises the price of ETH, that will hurt users (not holders) of the Ethereum blockchain via increased transaction fees. but this logic is flawed

@TheStalwart so bottom line, buyback of stocks is largely neutral (depending on ROI of the money inside vs outside the company), but buyback of ETH is very positive because it does not come from Ethereum's balance sheet but paying less to a supplier for the same service (genuine cost savings)

@TheStalwart 2) by changing the monetary policy (even in a purely positive way for eth holders), it loses some credibility with people who value extreme stability

both of those (security + credibility) can be seen as assets on ethereum's balance sheet. but imo the effect here is not big

@TheStalwart in EIP-1559, the fees being burned do equate buybacks in the sense that the eth supply goes down over time. but the money to buy back the eth does not come from Ethereum's balance sheet but rather from the miners' collective balance sheet.

@TheStalwart when evaluating a stock buyback (which is just a tax-optimized way of paying a dividend), then a priori there is no reason to see one option as more profitable than the other. that's bc as you said the money must be taken from the company's balance sheet

However, a node can't understand:
- which of two conflicting transactions (e.g. spend the same coin to Alex and Bob) is the canonical one
- which of two competing chains to prefer

This we cannot solve with cryptography - only incentives. Hence the need for mining/staking

Examples of an invalid block:
- minting yourself more than the coinbase reward
- spending someone else's coins
- using more than the legal block weight/gas limit

These are all things a node can check for cryptographically, and hence can easily reject

It‚Äòs cliche, but you should play long-term games with long-term people.

2) The second point is about both yourself & the people you work with. Days like yesterday are extremely useful in one way:

They pull away the curtain and reveal how people react in a (perceived) crisis situation.

In summary, today is a good day as any to join the club and start looking at any form of governance as an attack vector. Also, start looking at *complexity* as an attack vector. 

Use projects that minimize governance-extractable value:
https://t.co/QoJJVJ3N6I

But the reality is that opportunity makes the thief, and most hacks and rug pulls are insider jobs.

It doesn‚Äòt matter if you can trust a founder today. Can you trust them at their lowest moment, when they see their project & future revenue swimming away?

There are two important takeaways from this:

1) In theory, smart contracts allow us to build applications that require no trust in the developers.

In practice, there‚Äòs a near endless number of governance apologists, telling you that this or that loophole is necessary.

For most people, this means making self-destructive moves, like using high leverage to ‚Äûmake it all back in one trade‚Äú.

Others are willing to take from other people - by force.

Why do many hacks and rugpulls coincide with overall market downturns?

Same reason crime explodes in an economic depression. 

People stop seeing the market as a long-term positive-sum game.  Instead, they switch into survival mode, taking with force what the market ‚Äûowes‚Äú them.

https://t.co/mYoFr1sQ1z

I‚Äòve always been vocal that self-custody isn‚Äòt for everyone, most lost funds are due to user-error and not theft, and I still believe all of those things. But I think Argent is showing the space that user-friendly custody is possible without compromising on security.

Congrats!

Even if my phone AND app were compromised (which is already a stretch), the attacker couldn‚Äòt withdraw funds to untrusted addresses. 

Further, I can immediately lock my wallet remotely just by sending an on-chain txn from any guardian address.

Using a smart contract wallet allows me to define all kinds of spending conditions around daily amounts, trusted addresses and applications.

E.g. I can immediately sign a Uniswap trade to my own address, but not to any external address w/o signing from several of my guardians.

Guardian addresses are also stored on-chain, and they can be
* friends/family
* other hardware devices that you control
* your email+phone number (via Argent Guardian service)

A majority of them can replace your signer key.

So if you ever want to change the signer key (e.g. because your phone was lost/stolen/replaced), then you have to tell the smart-contract to update its signer key. This is where the social recovery part (via the guardians) comes in:

A smart-contract wallet, as the name suggests, is an on-chain contract. It has one signer key and several guardians (think of those as an on-demand multi-sig setup).

The signer key is generated in the Secure Enclave of your phone, and it can never leave from there. https://t.co/FTyOXMssUN

My workflow:
1) Establish an encrypted channel between Argent and a Defi app via Walletconnect. This only needs to be done once for each app.
2) Make all my txns on desktop
3) Review and sign the txn on the Argent mobile app, which acts as a 2FA

I would consider myself a power user of Argent and have onboarded several friends to become power users themselves.

The experience of using a smart contract wallet with social recovery is SO much better than any other type of custody setup IMO.

That answers one possible way to interpret @CryptoHayes words.. 

the other is that gas itself is becoming "too expensive", but as we showed gas is sold in a market based on supply and demand. 

By definition it cannot be too expensive if people are bidding up the price.

As a result, the transaction market can function on ANY amount of ETH (which is -  btw - infinitely divisible as well)

You can run the on-chain Ethereum economy on 1 ETH if necessary. In fact, most Ethereum killers implicitly do that because their fees are ~0 anyway

I'm not even sure what I'm reading @CryptoHayes.

But just in case:

Transactions on Ethereum have no fixed cost in ETH. They only have a cost in gas, a virtual unit.

Miners/stakers have a fixed amount of gas to allocate in every block.

Transactors bid for this gas in ETH. https://t.co/aVHHaiGLQq

Overall, I think this proposal deserves some attention, not just because PoW could become a liability for Bitcoin over the next years, but because it could help us solve the security trilemma in the long term. https://t.co/E8bgykTa8G

However, no change is without downsides:

Bitcoin hardware is at the brink of becoming commoditized, no single producer has an overwhelming lead anymore. Changing the algo now would reintroduce many old problems into the mining space

(as well as being highly charged politically) https://t.co/m1FKohhAmA

I have discussed the benefits of oPoW in a 2020 presentation at Value of Bitcoin conference. 

Higher share of CAPEX is strongly correlated with higher security, as well as lower risk of geographic centralization due to cheap energy cost. https://t.co/zY5Lq0t1iO

Optical proof-of-work (oPoW) is an alternative (hardware-based!) sybil-resistance mechanism for Bitcoin and other chains that reduces energy costs from currently 50% to about 10% of total miner expenditures.

It also has some interesting security implications

That's because dapp treasuries today tend to be denominated in their native token, e.g. UNI.

Actually using it will dilute existing holders.

But listing on secondary markets (like DEXs) has many advantages.

@nicksdjohnson @sunnya97 @epicenterbtc @algo_class Not for smaller GPU mineable coins but definitely for Bitcoin (100% ASICs) + Ethereum (~25% ASICS + biggest GPU mined coin)

@nicksdjohnson @sunnya97 @epicenterbtc @algo_class Mmh, not really. Several papers (e.g. my own https://t.co/Et64tMBQhS but others as well) have shown that mining hardware is priced as an option on future coins. So what you say about PoS applies to PoW just as well.
@nicksdjohnson @sunnya97 @epicenterbtc @algo_class As you say, all of the arguments in the paper are moot if miners actively collude with each other

@nicksdjohnson @sunnya97 @epicenterbtc @algo_class I know that you (and many others) hate relying on price as an incentive mechanism. But the expectation of future revenue (and how it is affected by various actions) IS the main incentive mechanism of Ethereum and any other blockchains.
@nicksdjohnson @sunnya97 @epicenterbtc @algo_class I'm not sure that we still call about volatility in the chain tip when miners are actively censoring the blockchain üòâ

@nicksdjohnson @sunnya97 @epicenterbtc @algo_class ETC has 0 users, it's basically just a number on a screen with no expectations of fundamentals. For how this could look when Bitcoin & Ethereum are affected, look at what happened in media & subsequently price after BitMEX research had erroneously detected a $5 double-spend

@nicksdjohnson @sunnya97 @epicenterbtc @algo_class It's not difficult to see why: Ethereum's public perception (and price!) depend on the optics that mining is decentralized. Anything that destroys this illusion is very negative for the price and for user activity on Ethereum and hence for miners as well.

@nicksdjohnson @sunnya97 @epicenterbtc @algo_class Another group of miners called for 51% of hashpower to connect to a single mining pool for 51 hours "to send a message". That was planned for April 1st. After intense community pushback, the protest never happened.

@nicksdjohnson @sunnya97 @epicenterbtc @algo_class Yup, see for example https://t.co/nWvjEuyPRo
I hope BBT doesn't mind if I describe him as a leader/representative of the small-mid miner community
@sunnya97 @gakonst Not really, it just gets into the discussion of what leverage users have over miners if they misbehave

@nicksdjohnson @sunnya97 @epicenterbtc @algo_class We could also remove the block subsidy. Only fair when miners take more txn fees than they are owed via the "fair use" of EIP-1559. This is a pretty simple and tangible counter, on top of the others.

@sunnya97 @gakonst To answer your question, yes, an MASF (same as any other attack) is more likely if users "don't care." However, that assumption is wrong here as users care very strongly about miners interacting with EIP-1559 as intended i.e. mining blocks above the gas target.

@nicksdjohnson @sunnya97 @epicenterbtc @algo_class See https://t.co/d6eCy2iPCO, once you include extrinsic incentives, you can break any system under the rationality assumption. IMO what we should do in practice is build systems that are robust to *some* amount of external incentives. For the rest, we need social coordination

@sunnya97 @nicksdjohnson @epicenterbtc @algo_class To verify that, all you have to do is follow the community/dev/miner debates earlier this year. Thousands in the community were very unhappy with miners for even suggesting they could stall EIP-1559 or ask for any concessions in return.

@sunnya97 @nicksdjohnson @epicenterbtc @algo_class *Any* rule that users didn't explicitly set violates social norms. Removing EIP-1559 as Ethereum's most highly anticipated feature via MASF would be a hardcore violation of social norms.
@sunnya97 @nicksdjohnson @epicenterbtc @algo_class I don't know and like what you're trying to incite here, but afaict "the fight over 1559" is conclusively over.

@nicksdjohnson @sunnya97 @epicenterbtc @algo_class Personally, I think it would lead to things like
* terrible press
* users mass-abandoning Ethereum for other blockchains
* price dumping
* txn fees dumping
* remaining users discussing PoW change + emergency PoS deployment. 

Bottom line, miners likely lose a lot
@nicksdjohnson @sunnya97 @algo_class True, I was wrong about that.

@nicksdjohnson @sunnya97 @algo_class Maybe I'm misunderstanding our argument. 
1) doing an MASF post-1559 is no more profitable than pre-1559
2) in both cases, it would lead to intense pushback from Ethereum users

do you agree with both?

@sunnya97 @nicksdjohnson @epicenterbtc @algo_class It will be incentive-compatible IF
1) there's a cartel of miners ready to orphan other miners
2) users don't care that the cartel orphans other miners
3) users don't care that the miners block EIP-1559 in a practical sense

1 may be possible, but 2+3 are definitely not

@nicksdjohnson @sunnya97 Miners don't MASF today because it would be seen as an attack on Ethereum, likely triggering intense pushback from users and investors and leading to lower revenue than just playing by the rules

@nicksdjohnson @sunnya97 Okay, if you're willing to orphan defective miners then you can control the basefee. But I think you already answered that it's also in the miners' best interest to do so today and e.g. charge higher gas prices.

@sunnya97 @nicksdjohnson This collective action problem has been discussed by @algo_class in https://t.co/09UhyHD0fC and also in shorter form in https://t.co/YJOwcXe3DA, finding that the risk of MASF is no bigger than today

@sunnya97 @nicksdjohnson concur @nicksdjohnson

If price of ETH goes up, txns *do* become more expensive, but only if the gas price in gwei stays the same as well.
This shows how txn costs are affected by all three factors: gas cost (changes rarely/never), gas price (fluctuates due to supply/demand), and ETH price (fluctuates due to supply/demand)

The way I tend to explain it is

Txns have a cost in gas (a ficticious resource)
Users bid for gas in Ether's smallest unit gwei.
Ether has a price in USD

Example: 
ERC-20 Transfer takes 21k gas
1 gas costs 50 gwei
21k gas cost 1,05m gwei
1,05m gwei = 0,0105 ETH = $28

I'd say pretty much none of it? Stakers don't want to hedge their exposure to ETH (hedged stakers won't be cost-competitive with unhedged ones), they want liquidity on it. 
https://t.co/b6VAX6e6E7

Given these constraints, I'd argue that the condition "give up least possible control of the base chain" is satisfied when a supermajority of stake is controlled by decentralized instead of centralized staking pools. This seems possible but is still an uphill battle.

The ETH2 developers set out to prevent delegation altogether by not supporting it on the protocol layer, but they underestimated how much users would demand this feature. IMO this was short-sighted and wrong, but we have to live with their decisions now.

I warned for at least two years that CEXs will dominate staking unless decentralized alternatives are made very attractive. Alas, Binance Kraken and Huobi together have more than 30% of all Beacon Chain stake already. This is before Coinbase has joined the staking game. https://t.co/jgNrjJAMoZ

If one or more decentralized staking pools don't win this market, then a centralized (CEX-based) staking pool will. Fighting the market on this is like fighting gravity. If you build a PoS protocol today, it is your *obligation* to build these features into the protocol layer.

So the question isn't really, should there be staking pools? We know there will be because their private benefit to stakers is so large. What we would be concerned with is what (type of) staking pool also leads to a good systemic outcome for Ethereum?

Let's see. We know that stakers *will* want to rehypothecate their stake, they *will* want to delegate validation, they *will* want instant exit liquidity, they *will* want to stake with less than 32 ETH...
https://t.co/AYuBDYuf42

2) trustless staking derivative at no additional cost. The token will be more attractive to hold and more composable in Defi than any trusted derivative issued by CEXs

3) CEXs might have reputational constraints against maximizing MEV, leading to lower yields

Second, can decentralized pools compete with CEXs? I think in our post we gave some strong arguments why that can be the case:

1) It's non-custodial and non-KYC. We know empirically people appreciate those, esp all else equal

I agree pooled staking initially looks like a commodity business but that's where the staking derivative comes in. The more liquid one pool's derivative becomes, the larger the incentive to stake with that pool. The token's network effect creates a moat.
https://t.co/6UZeItMEH4

6) tbh, I expected Uniswap v3 or one of the other next-gen exchanges to innovate heavily around this idea and was genuinely disappointed when I learned that none of them did. good to see Archer and Flashbots pick up the mantle.
5-cont) the frontrunning protection comes from the parameterization of your trade, which is nothing new. but it's nontheless very useful.

4) so with Archer you can set 0% slippage txns without extra cost if they don't execute. this makes using 0% slippage more viable.

5) it does not afford any "frontrunning protection" in the sense that if you submitted a 3% slippage trade to Archer, you'd ofc still get sandwiched

3) Archer's innovation is account abstraction via relay service: the miner gets only paid if the txn succeeds. there is no longer an *unconditional* fee attached to it, which would be paid even if a miner includes a failing txn.

Okay guys, after some back and forth, I now understand what Archer does:

1) users can already set slippage tolerance to 0% (much more on this in my next article for @paradigm )

2) this causes txn to either get filled or fail, which still costs gas

@Lanadeltrade1 @wilburforce_ LP = liquidity provider (market maker)
FIFO = first in first out (the first order in the book is the first to be filled)
This is both healthier for price takers as well as causing significantly fewer negative externalities (MEV, state bloat) than the HFT game.

Uniswap v3 can be seen as a limit order book approximation, but one important difference is on any given price movement, LPs are matched pro-rata instead of FIFO (h/t @wilburforce_). This changes the optimal LP strategy from who can be first to who can provide the most liquidity.

@anguschampion @TheStalwart @benchmarcc @zhusu Yeah, there's nothing magical about blockchains, all the benefits are downstream of having shared state. I just think creating the same conditions in the trad financial system would require major changes that we both know won't happen anytime soon

@TheStalwart @benchmarcc @zhusu There is no global legal system on the internet let alone a monopoly on violence that could carry out the judgements. That's the paradigm shift behind blockchains. They bring genuine properties rights to the internet for the first time which then enables rapid marketization.

@TheStalwart @benchmarcc @zhusu I wrote an article on this topic a while back. Its main premise is that blockchains establish strong property rights (a critical conditions for markets) without the need for a stable legal system https://t.co/OjHGjGuRDU

@TheStalwart @benchmarcc @zhusu Rather it's an amendment to the current system that is far more suited for economic activity over the internet, which knows no borders and where most users are anonymous or pseudoymous and don't have an established trust relationship

@TheStalwart @benchmarcc @zhusu I think it's a misunderstanding that Defi seeks to replace all uncollateralized loans (or rather: loans collateralized by the borrowers' ability to repay in the future, which is itself collateralized by their reputation and ability of the system to physically contain them)

@anguschampion @TheStalwart @benchmarcc @zhusu Because the arbitrage trade doesn't take place in the same database where you borrowed the money (the bank's). It all needs to happen in one central database where updates are processed sequentially not simultaneously
@TheStalwart @anguschampion @benchmarcc @zhusu I get what you mean in general, but Angus is wrong here.

@anguschampion @TheStalwart @benchmarcc @zhusu It's fundamentally technically impossible, yeah, because it relies on transactions being *atomic*, meaning either all transactions in a bundle execute or none of them execute

@TheStalwart @benchmarcc @zhusu With flashloans, a teenager from Pakistan can borrow a billion dollars at no risk to the lender to perform an arbitrage transaction across other Defi protocols. This greatly reduces the cost (and risk) of arbitrage, leading to higher mkt efficiency

@TheStalwart @benchmarcc @zhusu Building on a blockchain also enables some truly mindblowing operations that are impossible anywhere else. 

For ex, consider a so-called flashloan, which is a loan that only executes if it is successfully repaid in the same transaction and fails otherwise.

@TheStalwart @benchmarcc @zhusu I would say primarily
* removal of middlemen (trust is costly)
* removal of barriers, global democratization of financial services
* sandbox for financial innovation (tradfi is one of the hardest industries to innovate, fintech is window-dressing)

@TheStalwart @benchmarcc @zhusu For example, you can make the contract upgradeable, but only if 70% of all "equity" tokens vote in favor. And/or, upgrades can activate only after a 48 hour timelock, which would give users so time to evaluate new upgrades and withdraw if necessary

(7/x)

@TheStalwart @benchmarcc @zhusu Between these two extremes - completely static contracts, and completely upgradeable contracts - there are many possible options, and that is where most projects fall in practice. 

(6/x)

@TheStalwart @benchmarcc @zhusu As discussed earlier, new code can have bugs, and this is especially true for new projects.  The more control the operator has, the easier it is to protect user funds against bugs, so many projects choose to start centralized and decentralize over time

(5/x)

@TheStalwart @benchmarcc @zhusu This is of course highly dangerous for users - the new contract could steal all their coins - hence it requires a lot of trust in the opeartor, and is also vulnerable to attacks on said admin key.

(4/x)

@TheStalwart @benchmarcc @zhusu On the far other end of the spectrum, contracts can be fully upgradeable, often by a single admin key. The way this works is that the central operator can swap out the previous contract with a new one.

(3/x)

@TheStalwart @benchmarcc @zhusu For example, if you deposit funds into a liquidity pool as a market maker you know that unless there's a hidden bug in the code, no one other than you can withdraw your coins or prevent you from withdrawing it.

(2/x)
@TheStalwart @benchmarcc @zhusu Some of these protocols are either fully or partially upgradeable by a coin vote from their token holders. Treasury is typically also controlled by them.
@benchmarcc @TheStalwart @zhusu I would add it‚Äòs not even primarily an instrument for fundraising, but also growth marketing + creating robust decentralization of voting shares

2) Gas limit per block
@sendmoodz It's going to be very difficult for demand to stay above 25m gas for any extended period of time, in most cases I would expect it to dip back down after only a few blocks

@sendmoodz For example, if demand spikes above 25m, then only one block later the basefee will already be 12.5% higher, after 2 blocks it's 27%, after 5 five blocks 80%, after only 10 blocks it's 300%+
This means that 95-99%+ of the time, users will simply be able to pay the quoted price and reliably get their transaction mined in the next block.

So this shows it can only happen temporarily at the transition from normal demand -> burst demand. It‚Äôs not possible to know how common FPAs will be in the future, but our intuition is ‚Äúvery rare‚Äù. Most likely sub 5% of all blocks, and probably more like sub 1%.

When that happens, the system degrades to the first-price auction we know today. But with every consecutive block mined, basefee will rapidly rise until the point where demand is once again below 25m gas. (Actually, it will keep rising until demand is exacly 12.5m gas)

One consequence of this change is that blocks will almost never be full. The only time where this doesn‚Äôt hold is when demand to transact at the current price rises very fast to exceed the new maximum of 2 * the gas target (currently 25m gas).
There is still a hard cap set as 2x the current gas target (so 25m gas), but this cap‚Äîcalled the gas limit, same as today‚Äînow only exists to prevent DoS attacks on nodes.

EIP-1559 *effectively* removes the current fixed cap on quantity and instead fixes the price of transacting. That price‚Äîthe basefee‚Äîupdates automatically to target the same 12.5m quantity of gas consumed as today.

To cap the social cost, Ethereum currently puts a hard gas limit of 12.5m on blocks. As of right now, the marginal price of each unit of gas is around 120 Gwei. In other words, at a marginal price of 120 Gwei, there is 12.5m gas worth of demand to transact.

First, a quick excursion: Why do blockchains need to put a price on scarce resources anyway?
1) To maximize user welfare (allocate resources to those who gets the most utility from them)
2) To minimize the social cost txns have on other nodes

One of the most common questions we get around EIP-1559 is how predictable the price of getting into the next block will be. Or in other words, how often will you able to pay the current basefee + minimum tip compared to the system degrading to today‚Äôs first-price auction (FPA)?

@ilblackdragon @_vshapovalov @aeyakovenko @gakonst If demand exceeds the gas target, then basefee will rise every block until demand matches supply at 50% utilization. Then the basefee stabilizes. You should know this, you implemented the mechanism yourself.

@ilblackdragon @aeyakovenko @gakonst There‚Äòs no reason to use a tip >95% of the time. Even then you only need it if you want immediate inclusion. You can also bid no tip + a lower or higher basefee.

@aeyakovenko @gakonst Because basefee always updates to target 50% utilization, the congestion state should be very rare and short-lived though. My guess is, >95% of the time we are in the first state where you don‚Äòt have to worry about the miner tip at all.

@aeyakovenko @gakonst When the system *is* congested (demand > gas limit, which is 2x the gas target), then you have to pay the quoted basefee + bid in a first-price auction via the miner tip, same as today.

@aeyakovenko @gakonst Sounds like you are talking about a totally different mechanism. In EIP-1559 you can still pay to get your TX included in the next block, in fact it makes that far easier and predictable. You only have to pay quoted basefee + 1 gwei miner tip when the system is not congested

@zndtoshi Not anymore than you can consider a Bitcoin halving a monetary change. It's programmed into the protocol and hence predictable, pending small delays around the hard fork date.

If you did track them and made a calculcated bet that EIP-1559 and/or PoS would keep getting delayed, that is entirely fair. Frankly, I would have done the same thing.

Yes, EIP-1559 changes Ethereum's monetary policy, but the change has been coming for a long-time and is fully in line with Ethereum's core community values.

It you invested in mining hardware without tracking these developments, it's arguably your own fault.
@zndtoshi The transition to ETH2

In response to this, Ethereum's block subsidy has been reduced twice before, from 5 to 3 ETH in 2017, and from 3 to 2 ETH in 2019.

Since then, Ethereum's demand for security has arguably increased due to larger settlement volume and Defi, but not nearly as fast as txn fees.

EIP-1559 has been formally proposed more than two years ago, and research into has started earlier still.

Same goes for the concept of Minimum Viable Issuance (stating that block rewards should track demand for security, not demand to transact).

Not to pick on any miner specifically, but there seems to be the one-sided idea that users have to consider the demands of miners, but miners don't have to follow protocol development or community values in any way.

After considering their feasibility & cost, we find that any form of aggressive protesting would damage long-term miner revenue more than cooperating with users.

We test this hypothesis by examining the two most effective ways for miners to protest the proposal: (1) fork Ethereum to create an altcoin without EIP-1559; and (2) block EIP-1559 on Ethereum by driving the basefee to zero.

In this post, @gakonst and I explore different ways the upcoming EIP-1559 activation could play out. Although it may seem counterintuitive, we hypothesize that the best strategy for miners is to support the proposal.

@thegostep @TimBeiko @sendmoodz @gakonst @paddypisa @William94029369 @anydotcrypto For the analysis of escalator algorithms Tim alluded to, check out: https://t.co/oOyFoJxAhd 

The below diagram summarizes it perfectly: An escalator merely makes first-price auctions a little less terrible. EIP-1559 replaces them with a fundamentally better mechanism. https://t.co/56M5bwEzCg

@thegostep @TimBeiko @sendmoodz @gakonst @paddypisa @William94029369 @anydotcrypto To understand how it relates to a fee escalator: >95% of the time (maybe more) there will be no need to guess the txn fee and hence no need to escalate because you guessed too low.

That's because there is always extra room in blocks and if you pay the quoted price, you get in.

PS: Mb needless to say, but whichever lender implements this first will probably have a big advantage with users from the US and Europe.

PSS: It applies to DEXs as well and every other protocol that has deposit tokens.

One protocol that doesn‚Äôt force a deposit token on their users is @MakerDAO, so keep that in mind if this thread applies to you. For a longer read on the topic, see
https://t.co/N8dggtRpp1

Classifying these deposits as sales makes no sense to me and better guidance might come in the future. But the lenders are in a position to improve the situation *today*: by asking the user whether they want to receive a deposit token or not.

Deposit tokens are one of Defi‚Äòs big innovations because they allow the deposit from one protocol to be used as collateral in a second protocol. But this is clearly a big problem, since users inadvertently sell coins they would have otherwise hodled to reach long-term tax status.

Lending protocols like @compoundfinance, @AaveAave, @CreamdotFinance needlessly punish users from the US and all of Europe. How? Whenever you deposit coins you receive a deposit token. Based on my research and experience, this tends to be classified as a sale of the collateral.
