The second biggest mistake investors make with regards to volatility is to overindex on short time frames.

When your investment horizon is 2 years, you don't have to worry what happens in between these two points.

One of the biggest mistakes investors make is to fear volatility.

Yes, volatility is bad, but *only* ceteris paribus - all else equal!

Very often all else is not equal, and investors could earn a much higher return by enduring a little more volatility.

Blockchains, in that sense, are their own legal systems.

Users and builders can choose between a wide range of possible rulesets.

Not every ruleset optimizes every possible usecase.

Code is not law, but code is a lot *like* law. 

Both create value by restricting human behavior.

Also, both can be changed when society agrees that they should.

Unlike in L1 consensus, the operator's bond doesn't need to scale with the value locked or economic activity in the rollup

One of my resolutions for 2021 was to shit-talk projects less on social media and make more constructive improvement proposals in governance instead. So I went ahead and wrote a short proposal for this to Maker https://t.co/aSm3hfOrCM

@udiWertheimer Good points, yeah. Good risk management is key here

Maker/Aave/etc. will let you borrow and withdraw $50k Dai vs $100k ETH, but they will let you borrow and *use* $500k Dai vs $100k ETH, as long as it controls what you spend it for and can liquidate you any time.

No identity and no trust required.

For example, you can tell a protocol to buy or sell them to create a specific-price exposure, to deposit them in a specific AMM pool, etc. This is how margin trading on exchanges has worked for decades!

And it's going to usher in the next stage of evolution in lending protocols.

üí°It is completely incorrect to say that Defi only supports overcollateralized lending.

You can, in theory, borrow $1m against $100k collateral. How? The kicker is that you can't withdraw the coins and walk away - instead you tell the lending protocol to use them on your behalf.

@emilianobonassi You can always unwind in a single transaction (conditional the lending pool has enough capital to pay out - if it doesn‚Äòt, you earn exponentially growing amounts of interest). But the above liquidity (not solvency) risk exists is the same even if you just lend and nothing else.
@romanyit Nope, it‚Äòs not a derivative. This is different.

There is, by the way, no leverage involved in any of this. You increase your exposure to different platform security risks, but not any additional market risks (i.e. you couldn‚Äòt get liquidated if the market moves against you)

There is no reason why the same pair of tokens shouldn‚Äòt be
1) swapped against to earn trading fees
2) borrowed against to earn interest
3) rebalanced to implement a fixed-weight investment strategy
4) ...all the while earning platform equity via yield-farming
Defi hasn‚Äòt even realized 10% of its full potential yet. The unlocking of LP tokens is what kicks us into the second gear in terms of capital-efficiency and composable yields.

"[we] expect Bridgewater to soon offer an alt-cash fund and a storehold of wealth fund in order to better deal with the devaluation of money and credit that we consider to be a major risk and opportunity, and Bitcoin won‚Äôt escape our scrutiny." - Dalio

To end, here are the two money quotes:

"[...] Bitcoin looks like a long-duration option on a highly unknown future that I could put an amount of money in that I wouldn‚Äôt mind losing about 80% of."
By the way, Dalio with the shot against S2F type models: "Since the supply is known, one has to estimate the demand to estimate its price."

Dalio thinks that Bitcoin's achilles heel is its lack of privacy. While very experienced users can use it privately, most people can't, and that would make it easy for governments to prevent wide-spread adoption as money. (I fully agree.) (p2)

Though Dalio knows about the ability to hold coins in cold storage, he's still concerned about the ability to shield them against cyber attacks and hold them securely. He warns that increasing digitization also increases systemic risk. (p2)

Dalio challenges the idea that Bitcoin is as scarce as people think, since there is an unlimited number of "Bitcoin-like assets". More innovative coins can probably carve out their own demand, and arguably we are already seeing that today. (p1)

Some money quotes in Dalio's note on Bitcoin

"It seems to me that Bitcoin has succeeded in crossing the line from being a highly speculative idea that could well not be around in short order to probably being around and probably having some value in the future." (p1)

@ggmesh "But Alice did try to bump the same outputs on two different transactions? Which is a little odd, no?" 

could be an inexperienced user, the wallet acting out, experimentation, etc. We can only speculate about her intentions, but not know them.

@ggmesh That's why accepting 1-conf is not recommended, as such natural reorgs can still happen occasionally.

However, I think my analysis showed that she was the owner of all involved outputs anyway.

@ggmesh her T1 was stuck for almost 24 hours before the bumped it.

2) She could speculate on a random stale block happening, which is very rare. In that case, she could double-spend Bob who only waited for 1 confirmation.

@ggmesh If you look at the counterfactual, Alice actually trying, to double-spend, there are only two ways for her to do that without hashpower:

1) Publish the bump txn in very fast succession to trick a merchant who accepts zero-conf. We can completely rule this out because...
@ggmesh Thanks! Everything points towards Alice just trying to bump her original txn in different ways.
@wintercooled I have no idea what Lucas could mean by that
@wintercooled I think we agree then that it means bouncing a check to another user?

@wintercooled Never seen anyone compare it to an inflation bug. If that was the case, both the sender + receiver would have the coin and the supply would be inflated. That's clearly not the case in Bitcoin, in a double-spend the transaction is reverted and the same coin is taken back.

@wintercooled I also disagree that's a double spend (but yes, that gets to the heart of last couple days' debate) because users can invalidate their own transactions for different reasons without affecting anyone else.

@wintercooled Basically my point is, if an actual double-spend happened no user would be comforted by the idea that it wasn't on the same chain but the network collectively switched to a heavier chain that doesn't contain their transaction.
@wintercooled "Spending the same UTXO twice on the same chain" would be a pointless definition as long as nodes still switch to the heaviest chain.
@wintercooled Neither of these https://t.co/s7ctFXntgW

@CryptoSecundus Yup, but IMO its range of possible inflation rates is wide enough to all its total carry cost unpredictable.

As we can see, there is no silver bullet when it comes to the economic security of public blockchains. It is always derived from volatile user demand. We can‚Äôt suppress that volatility, but we can change its release valve, depending on the core values of each community. https://t.co/skuyWVYcNU

In Ethereum, validators are paid primarily with inflation, establishing a predictable floor for security. Inflation can be offset by deflation from burning transaction fees. But demand to transact is once again uncertain, making the total inflation rate is unpredictable.

In the future, inflation in Bitcoin will go to zero, and miners are paid only with transaction fees. Since demand is uncertain, the size of the miner reward (and hence network security) is unpredictable.

Most people in crypto are used to thinking about inflation as a purely social or monetary design choice. But a cryptocurrency's inflation rate is also a lever to shift the volatility of demand between having a predictable cost for users OR a predictable level of security. https://t.co/bkjXbvRQGT

@RajarshiMaitra I agree, and I encourage equally defensive thinking when it comes to applications on Ethereum that could be seen as legal arbitrage (which applies to all of the most interesting ones). If it‚Äôs not costly to take down, it‚Äòs not interesting

@heliben2 And code is never law, it can only make changes more costly. Hope you took that away from the thread. Bitcoin once had an 8 *billion* btc supply inflation bug. Imagine telling yourself that we‚Äòre now stuck with that because ‚Äûcode is law‚Äú

@heliben2 Not really, I think it‚Äôs totally fair to call this ‚Äûrolling back a narrative‚Äú, but that‚Äòs not inherently bad. Social contracts are constantly renegotiated and the people who once pushed for a fixed-cap YFI might not even be the same people who hold YFI today.

@heliben2 Yeah most are not designed to be immutable, i.e. the team hasn‚Äòt made it costly to update the supply and the scarcity is not a core reason why people hold the token. Both of those make a lot of sense for *equity* tokens, and would make v little sense for *money* tokens

@NeedaShruberry That‚Äòs the short answer, the nuanced one is that who gets to keep the token ticker is an extremely messy process, especially if some people remain on the old chain/contract and are intent on keeping it alive.
@NeedaShruberry Is present-day BTC a new token because we once switched to a new blockchain without the 8 billion BTC supply inflation bug?
@RajarshiMaitra And Bitcoin hasn‚Äòt survived because enforcers are slow at their job, yeah? You think it has been invulnerable for 12 years?

@udiWertheimer An alternative view is the laws will eventually get updated to accommodate the new innovation as they are no longer enforceable, and it puts the ‚Äûhome team‚Äú at a severe disadvantage.

*All* scarcity in blockchains is at its root social, but the technical implementation can still affect how hard it is to change. In Bitcoin, the costs up updating scarcity would be unbearably high. For an Ethereum token that cost is much lower, and that‚Äòs also ok.

No, because anyone can make a new version of the token contract and if the community is sufficiently motivated they can migrate over. It‚Äòs the exact same as in Bitcoin: we could all switch to a new version without the supply cap - it‚Äòs just extremely unlikely.

Good question, and the answer is both yes and no.

Yes, because a smart contract can be immutable incl. by its creator.  Contracts can be upgradeable (by an admin key or a governance vote) but they don‚Äòt have to. Example: no one can take down or change a Uniswap pool.
@udiWertheimer I‚Äòm talking about the app layer on Ethereum fwiw. Not other L1 blockchains, especially not highly centralized ones

@udiWertheimer I think it's all about the marginal cost of taking something down. On Ethereum it can be outside of the founder's own control once sufficiently decentralized, and then it can't be taken down without taking down Ethereum itself

6) You'd think that this leads to strictly more borrow/lending volume but I'm not sure yet. The nice thing with overcollateralized loans is that they always add more liquidity to the lending book than they remove as borrowers.
5) In general I'm very curious how often the interest is settled, what happens if a protocol exceeds their credit limit, etc.

My question would be how this surge pricing interacts with zero collat loans. The interest they owe can rise, but if they only settle once a week, then either some borrowers can't withdraw in the short term or some of the non-whitelisted lenders get extremely rekt

4) Cream's interest rate is dynamic and changes as a result of borrow utilization. I think above 80% borrowed the interest rate for borrowers doubles every 8 hours to ensure there's always liquidity for lenders to withdraw

Good way of thinking about SNX staking:

Every sUSD you borrow from Syntethix is not one atomic risk position but two:
1) long sUSD
2) short BTC/ETH/Defi

Makes it clear you need to either hedge 2) or outperform it in other ways.

@iamDCinvestor You only get the sUSD by borrowing them from Synthetix. So you're long sUSD and short BTC/ETH/Defi, which makes it extremely risky. Also, you're part of the same debt pool as the rest of us, so unless you snapshotted you should have lost the same as me (12% in Dec, 9% in Nov)

@Chloethedev @TimBeiko @VitalikButerin @drakefjustin I have no idea where you get this idea. Exchanges will allow users to stake their ETH with a one-directional bridge (can stake, but not unstake, only sell on the exchange). Every other method would have virtually 0 upside for exchanges but lots of downside

As a result, it not only can't prevent the formation of ETH/BETH, but also incentivizes TWO dangerous precedents:
1) centralized/custodial staking
2) securitization of stake (terribly for security, introduces principal-agent problems)

Disabling transfers incentivizes the securization of BETH via staking through centralized exchanges. Those exchanges will allow users to trade in and out of BETH, which will be a significant value-add over non-custodial staking.

Drake and Vitalik both seem to think that disabling transfers in phase 0 can prevent the formation of a secondary BETH asset (beacon chain ETH). I disagree and predict that it will achieve the opposite.

@RyanTheGentry @musatheredguard It is for you, in my experience most people are still firmly in the "tragedies of the commons don't exist" stage. It's a persistent problem with libertarians in general
@Breedlove22 @evoskuil what was the disagreement about?

this trend is further indicated by more and more coins adopting EIP-1559, which in scenarios where the chain is heavily used, even REWARDS coin holders with deflation. you think people will prefer 0% inflation over 1% deflation because it's some magic number?

if inflation can actually provide these material benefits for security/sustainability, then an altcoin with this property will obviously do really well. this holds for both "non-btc" altcoins and forks of BTC, but only one of them would carry on Bitcoin's soul, the UTXO set...

this outcome is 100% in line with what we strongly believe about the market, namely that other properties held ~equal it favors the lowest inflation coin. no one in their right mind advocates for a higher-inflation coin if it didn't give other material benefits.
as a result, it's pretty likely that coins without this problem have low perpetual inflation, which you should simply think of as a mandatory tax on holders to prevent the tragedy of the commons.

possible solutions to tragedies of the commons are well established both in theory & practice and one of the best is to make security excludable. you do that by funding security from a mandatory tax (inflation) instead of voluntary transaction fees, thereby preventing free riders

@VitalikButerin @j_larrieux @Tetranode I think you misread, I said eth2 sacrifices A, not P. As I understand (and correct me if necessary) every distributed consensus system needs P, the design space is choosing between (degrees of) A and C.
@juliankoh why acquire their own portfolio co?
@j_larrieux @Tetranode @VitalikButerin Yes it's a spectrum, I was simplifying for clarity

@Tetranode so my point is, what you call finality doesn't come for free, it's a design decision with its own tradeoffs and its tangential to PoW/PoS. you can add finality to any blockchain if you're willing to sacrifice liveness.

@Tetranode bitcoin favors A and P, and sacrifices C (you can have reorgs of any depth), whereas ETH with PoS favors C and P, and sacrifices A (when a reorg >x blocks is detected, the chain halts and must be manually restarted)

@Tetranode there's a concept in distributed computing called the CAP theorem. it posits that a system can only guarantee two out of the three properties (C)onsistency, (A)vailability, and (P)artition tolerance.

I think things are actually changing a lot in Bitcoin, but they are more related to market structure than the core protocol. A high predictability of the latter is what enables the former.

@dandolfa @C1aranMurray - can offer lower fees bc of there's basically no overhead. There's a Uniswap team that develops new features, but even if they walked away Uniswap would function the same way it does today into perpetuity

@dandolfa @C1aranMurray Uniswap has had higher trading volume than Coinbase for a while now. Why?
- it supports thousands of assets that Coinbase would never list (or can't for regulatory reasons)
- anyone can trade, no signup or KYC
- it's non-custodial, as txns are done atomically

@dandolfa @C1aranMurray As long as there is liquidity in these pools, it means they will always trade with you. that makes them a core building block for other applications that rely on external liquidity, e.g. for collateral liquidations

@dandolfa @C1aranMurray The way these pools quote prices is algorithmic, where the product of two tokens must always be constant (so the more demand there is to buy one token, the higher its price will go)

@dandolfa @C1aranMurray It's an exchange that's completely permissionless to use. Anyone can create more trading pairs (so called liquidity pools), anyone can provide liquidity to them (maker) and anyone can take liquidity from them (taker)
@tomhschmidt @TheBlock__ Facts

@dandolfa @C1aranMurray Liquidity provision is crypto's word for market making (yes, we need to reinvent everything from scratch to see if the old world's any good). So there's no credit involved. Uniswap is an exchange

@iamDCinvestor Think about it like this: you want to maximize the accumulative value of asset + dividends.

Whether you store them in one or two tokens has zero impact on their value. But what has a huge impact is permanent outflow in the form of taxes and gas.
@ceterispar1bus If the system is poorly designed, yes. But in Curve's case, they would buy and burn veCRV?
@wekawork2 yeah, that's a great one

@iamDCinvestor dividends don't give you any guarantees about the price of the base asset either. with buy-and-burn, you can replicate the dividends experience if you just sell some of your coins on a fixed schedule.

You should prefer buy and burn even if you live in a jurisdiction where you don't pay taxes on dividends yourself (such as Singapore). The reason is that a tax on other holders will still come to bite you in the form of additional sell pressure.

If you want to maximize effective reward to your investors, there's really only one choice: Buy and burn.

It saves a tremendous amount in both gas and taxes. Using dividends in crypto is a double-tax on all holders.

what's the takeaway?

all the new demand to mint $dai from yEarn pushes Maker into a state where $dai trades at or below a dollar.

as a result, Maker could start charging stability fees again. something they couldn't do for months.

because of its design, Maker can only make money when demand to mint $dai exceeds the demand to hold it (by charging minters the stability fee)

if they supported negative interest rates, they could also charge holders, but that prob won't happen and has its own tradeoffs anyway.

Maker's trouble this year is well documented:

because there was too much demand to hold $dai and too little demand to mint it, $dai has traded consistently above a dollar. 

as a result, MKR had to lower all stability fees (and hence all revenues) to zero
https://t.co/33xI3l91AC

the popular yETH vault mints $dai against $eth to supply liquidity to Curve. several dynamics to watch here:

* the vault is pushing $dai supply up (by 70m so far), which pushes the price down toward a dollar
* adding $yfi as collateral would be another source of demand to mint

@least_nathan I haven't looked into the cousin proposal yet, but can you give me the tldr on how it relates to 1559? what features are the same or different?
if Zcash adopted perpetual issuance + fee burn, I'd like that a lot
@least_nathan no drafts yet, in terms of timeline we'd like to put something out before 2020 is over.

@least_nathan 1559 gives you the guarantee that miners will earn AT LEAST x% in issuance, and that guarantee is really valuable for consensus stability. burning fees plays very nice with that, because it ensures that you don't pay much MORE than x% either.

@least_nathan personally, I think supporting multiple tokens is a great benefit, not just for fees, but also because it can make the native token MORE rather than less useful. for example, because that allows you to have DEXs rather than CEXs

@least_nathan it exacerbates it in the sense that when users handle multiple tokens, you create demand among them to use these tokens to pay fees (e.g. so they can hold USDT only without also holding ZEC for fees)
@least_nathan so the answer would be: it's a concern when AE is used so much that it has a strong effect on token price - not really before that.

@least_nathan but to answer the question, EA is a concern because the native token needs to be valuable in order for public blockchains to securely support a lot of economic activity.

when you hold activity constant but make the token lose its value, the system can lose its security

@least_nathan to clarify, by economic abstraction you mean = people pay fees in the non-native currency?

outside of transaction accelerators (which are only used at a tiny scale) I'm not aware of any such economic abstraction happening in Bitcoin or Zcash.

@ercwl @austerity_sucks @crypto_delboy That‚Äòs not how it works. Binance (or Bitfinex) does not need to burn a specific amount of BNB (LEO), only a specific amount of $ worth of BNB (or LEO).

A $10 trade will trigger a $10 buy order, irregardless of BNBUSD prices. If that price is high, less BNB is burned.

1) Binance holds BNB in treasury
Trader pays $10 fee
Binance takes $10 from treasury
Binance burns $10 BNB

2) Binance sells $10 BNB for $10
Trader pays $10 fee
Binance sells $10 to buy $10 BNB
Binance burns $10 BNB

In both cases, Binance +/-0, trader -$10, and BNB holders +$10

These coins in the treasury have to be counted toward the overall supply. Every day Binance does not sell their BNB is functionally equivalent to them buying the BNB.

Example: (cont)

Some people are correctly pointing out that not every trading fee is paid in BNB, and so it has to burn more than it receives from traders. These BNB are taken from their treasury. 

The overall point still holds, because BNB has no obligation whatsoever to even hold BNB.
@austerity_sucks @crypto_delboy ‚ÄûNot selling X‚Äú is functionally equivalent to ‚Äûbuying X‚Äú on any given day.
@crypto_delboy You‚Äòre making my point?
@MLescrauwaet Yes. Big fan of the AMH

@crypto_delboy I don‚Äòt see how that contradicts what I said. Tokens in Binance treasury have to be counted toward supply since they represent future inflation. Of course you‚Äòll end up with a flawed mental model by excluding them from supply, but that‚Äòs your fault then.

LEO: 
Trader pays $10 in fees
Bitfinex sells $10 to buy $10 LEO 
Bitfinex burns the $10 LEO
Result: Bitfinex +/- 0, trader -$10, LEO holders +$10

BNB:
Trader pays $10 BNB in fees
Binance burns the $10 BNB
Result: Binance +/- 0, trader -$10, BNB holders +$10

QED

I keep hearing this but BNB‚Äòs buy-and-burn mechanism is functionally the same as LEO‚Äòs. 

Binance also buys the tokens it burns, it‚Äòs only less obvious because the buy happens at the same time as the provision of trading and other services.

@benediktbuenz @bramcohen now you could take it even further and ask, doesn't this convergence on a single "ruleset" create this huge incentive for the most resourceful pros to discover a strategy that explicitly uses rules that the population can't understand? (9/n)

@benediktbuenz @bramcohen so going back to my original tweet, the game of poker is not actually playing it, that's just one small part of it. it's predominantly building new strategies that do well against the population of other players, and doing it in a resourceful way. (8/n)

@benediktbuenz @bramcohen as a result, players who make their own bots are strongly incentivized to understand the betsizes *their opponents use* in order to respond well to them. do you see why it's then so likely that the entire player base eventually converges on the same set of betsizes? (7/n)

@benediktbuenz @bramcohen the other one is that a simple bot that uses betsizes {A,B,C} also can't understand betsizes other than {A,B,C} when an opponent uses them. it has to translate them to whatever is closest among {A,B,C} and hope the mistake won't be too large. (6/n)

@benediktbuenz @bramcohen so we start from this place where most players have this strong incentive to limit the number of betsizes they use because that's what they studied and understand. that is one part of the puzzle (5/n)

@benediktbuenz @bramcohen what you're actually looking for is a the smallest possible abstraction of poker that still maps well onto the real, much more complex game. one super-obvious way to do this is to limit the amt of legal betsizes. (4/n)

@benediktbuenz @bramcohen these GTO bots can't credibly cover the whole game tree - even if you wanted to spend millions of dollars on them, it would be LESS useful than a smaller bot with more limited options. the reason is that the more complex you make the game, it harder to gets to study. (3/n)

@benediktbuenz @bramcohen all pros operate in a resource-constrained environment: time + money + memory + brain cycles. they want to make as much money as possible given these constraints, and the optimal way to do this for many years has been to study using GTO bots. (2/n)

@benediktbuenz @bramcohen hi, ex poker pro and GTO expert here. in order to understand why this was always going to be the equilibrium among players and is not surprising, you need to expand your definition of what the game of poker actually is. (1/n)

@fubuloubu 2) in EIP-1559 miners don't "accept burned fees". they have to pay the minimum fee to include any txns at all, and if they're economically rational they recoup it from users.
@fubuloubu 1) no one would pay ANY basefee, because why should they if it's a) not mandatory, and b) doesn't help them get into a block?

and if you do set a protocol-enforced minimum fee, then you really want it to be dynamic and not static. so there's no point in entertaining this idea, unfortunately (we have tried to find a way to break up EIP-1559 into smaller components - we just didn't find a way how)

Re: "we can burn fees without full EIP-1559":

it's not actually possible to do basefee+tip without the elastic blocksize component that sets a protocol-enforced minimum fee. if you did that, no one would pay any basefee and hence nothing would be burned. all fees'd be in the tip

@soupcowboys That's what inspired me to write this article: The public thinks governance has been fully handed over without realizing that all money in vaults was still custodied by Cronje alone. I don't say that it shouldn't be, but the public should make that decision with full info.

@soupcowboys Control over minting YFI was handed over on July 21st, but this did not cover the controller contract which can assign new strategies to vaults (incl. ones that drain the vaults completely). That was handed over yesterday, the relevant transaction is linked in the article.

Most DeFi users are not aware that all governance-heavy protocols are more-or-less custodial. A system like https://t.co/rQn46K66UQ that relies on rapidly adapting to market conditions will likely always fall on the side of needing more control at the expense of deposit security.

I didn't necessarily intend for Cronje to give up control, as there were good reasons the protocol was set up that way. Instead, I wanted to educate investors about what trust assumptions go into using a protocol such as https://t.co/rQn46K66UQ.

TLDR: Between the launch of yVaults on July 25th and August 6th, the main developer Andre Cronje was in control of $40m of customer funds. On August 6th he handed the relevant governance rights to the 6-of-9 wallet of community stakeholders that also controls YFI minting.

My analysis of governance rights in @iearnfinance reveals DeFi's struggle to balance governance rights with deposit safety for customers. Users should not think of it as non-custodial but as an actively managed fund, controlled by a small number of humans. https://t.co/b2zItR86Hn

@dankrad I googled for a bit, but didn‚Äòt find a comprehensive overview. Would appreciate the color!

Some people raised that centrally controlled allocation of resources leads to less optimal outcomes for society than decentralized one, but that‚Äòs tangential to the question. I think it‚Äòs incredibly hard to argue that the bottom 50% aren‚Äòt net winners from taxation and inflation.
In summary, both taxation and inflation are methods of *redistribution* from the haves to the have-nots.
Whoever pays the inflation tax, we again know it‚Äòs not going to be the bottom 50% because they don‚Äòt own a lot of cash and many of them are even net debtors.

Now much of that is held in home and business equities, but for cash (and I count fixed-income securities into that) the story won‚Äòt look very different. The bottom 30% effectively have a networth of 0 or negative.

It would help if we knew where US balances are being held by wealth or income bracket, but we can use networth as a shortcut: US households have an average net worth of $692,100 and a median net worth of $97,300.

Source: https://t.co/P7YDMUUTmj

On Bitcoin Twitter, near-everyone would agree that inflation is a form of tax on currency holders. If the bottom 50% are huge net winners from regular taxation, how can they possibly be net losers from inflation?

When framed in this way, it‚Äòs safe to assume the bottom 50% benefit disproportionately from the ‚Äûinsurance services‚Äú offered by the US government.

Moving on to inflation, even more people (8 out of 9) answered the bottom 50% are net losers. https://t.co/BPYDiKdHQQ

‚ÄûAbout $2.7 trillion -- more than two-thirds of the total -- went for various kinds of social insurance (Social Security, Medicaid and Medicare, unemployment compensation, veterans benefits and the like).‚Äú

Source: https://t.co/1X6KUVHaCX

So we know the bottom 50% pay hardly any taxes *at all*, but where does the money go?

‚ÄûPew Research broke down how the US federal government spent $3.95 trillion in 2016, noting that the country is basically a giant insurance company that has a side business in defense‚Äú

‚ÄûIn 2016, the top 50 percent of all taxpayers paid 97 percent of all individual income taxes, while the bottom 50 percent paid the remaining 3 percent.‚Äú

Further, the average tax rate was 4% in the bottom 50% and 16% in the top 50%.

Source: https://t.co/R3ig5aShpW

I did a series of polls yesterday and the results surprised me, to say the least. Over half of you think the bottom 50% of US Americans are net losers from taxation. Here‚Äòs why I disagree: https://t.co/1cb47NVRM4

Rephrasing the original question:
If a company has the power to unilaterally increase Bitcoin‚Äòs blocksize by 30%, should it do so?

But in practice, users either download and validate all extension blocks or trust that rules of the extension block are followed, degrading their security model to quasi SPV nodes. So the extension block is really mandatory and should be treated same as other blocksize increases.

So the benefit for some usecases (transacting) comes at a higher cost for others (receiving/validating). A popular response to this is that the Segwit soft fork is ‚Äûoptional‚Äú and users could run older software if they wanted to.

Segwit transactions are cheaper because they leverage an extension block in addition to the existing 1 MB blocksize limit. If @blockchain adopts Segwit, Bitcoin‚Äòs effective blocksize increases. That can lower txn costs, but would increase validation costs.

There might be good reasons not to use @blockchain‚Äòs Bitcoin wallet and I refer to @matt_odell‚Äòs authority on this issue, but I have problems with the argument that ‚Äûno Segwit == anti Bitcoin‚Äú
To my lawyer friends and -followers: I‚Äòd love to hear of any cases where this paragraph was applied and how it is used in practice.

@BobMcElrath @lopp @pwuille Yup, that‚Äòs a great resource! It covers points 1+2, though not point 3
As a result, hashrate ATHs have to be evaluated together with hardware replacement cycles. ATHs at the beginning of a new cycle often indicate temporarily weaker, not stronger security for Bitcoin.

3) After older hardware becomes unprofitable for most levels of electricity cost, it enters secondary markets where it can be cheaply accumulated by an attacker who may not mind about bleeding money over time.

The former is unilaterally good for security, but the latter is not: 
1) Difficulty can increase as miner spend stagnates or even decreases. 
2) Better hardware makes proofs-of-work generated with older, less efficient hardware easier to undo.

Caveat (obv @lopp knows this but some people may not):

Mining difficulty does not translate 1:1 to security. Difficulty is a function of money spent on mining but also of improvements in mining hardware.

Can we at least call Liquid a ‚Äúfederated sidechain‚Äù then? Once again, this would be the same as a ‚Äúfederated cryptocurrency‚Äù - a thing that, by definition, cannot exist.

This analysis shows why statements 1) and 2) are correct.

I'm not going along with this because calling Liquid a sidechain is equivalent to calling XRP or Libra a cryptocurrency. The defining feature of a cryptocurrency is not a token on a blockchain, but a system that operates with very little trust.

A sidechain was once considered distinct from a blockchain because users could transfer assets trustlessly between chains. This distinction is now gone, and a sidechain and a blockchain have morphed into the exact same thing.

In the past, no one has argued harder than the Bitcoin community that the term blockchain is actually meaningless - and rightly so. It says nothing about the properties of a system we are trying to describe. All that matters is the trust model.
Even Blockstream calls this a trusted system AND a sidechain, so what‚Äôs their new working definition? Simple: a sidechain is now any chain of blocks. Let that sink in.

Further, there‚Äôs a second federation of 3 (think: admin keys) after consensus has stalled for two weeks. Since it needs 11 of 15 operators to make a new block, 5 of them can stall the blockchain indefinitely, and then 2 of 3 admins can steal your coins as well.
They did this by launching Liquid with a closed federation of 15 block producers rather than an open PoW chain. In this system, 11 of 15 operators can steal your coins at any time.

Now you could think that the idea of the sidechain died together with the hope for this script extension. But this is not what happened: Blockstream simply relaxed the definition of a sidechain so it no longer needs to be trustless.

The goal was to implement this with a ‚Äúbidirectional peg‚Äù. To do this form of peg-out, Bitcoin needed to be able to verify the other blockchain‚Äôs proof-of-work. This capability would have required a change to Bitcoin that later turned out infeasible.

A sidechain was first introduced as a ‚Äútechnology to support the movement of assets between blockchains‚Äù with the two key properties:
1) only the current owner of a coin can withdraw it
2) the withdrawal of a coin cannot be blocked

In short, it should be trustless.

I‚Äôll argue both of my statements are true and you should stop calling Liquid a sidechain.

As a result, I reject the statement that "banks multiply reserves into loans". Thoughts/corrections welcome!

Likewise, if private sector demand to borrow is low (e.g. due to economic uncertainty), very few bank deposits are created. 

Increasing the number of reserves affects neither (1) nor (2). We can confirm that by looking at countries like Canada that have no reserve requirements.

When banks lend too much money to un-creditworthy customers, their liabilities and assets go out of whack and the bank runs the risk of going broke. This shows that their ability to create loans is primarily constrained by the capital part of the balance sheet.

For every loan a bank makes, they create a deposit on the liability side which is backed by a financial asset on the asset side of their balance sheet. The financial asset can be the customer's future ability to repay or a more tangible form of collateral, like a house.

Pushing more reserves on banks does not get them to lend more. Instead, banks can already get all the reserves they need from the overnight market (where banks lend to themselves overnight) or from the Fed itself.

It is correct that banks create money (actually, they create deposits, which is the dominant form of money today) by debt monetization. But the amount of money creation is never constrained by reserves and always by having (1) enough capital and (2) enough private sector demand.

The folk view is banks can take these reserves and lend them to the private sector (up to the reserve limit), thereby "multiplying" the money via credit creation. This view is incoherent with how banks actually create money.

While the private sector uses commercial bank IOUs to clear their payments, these banks use the Fed to clear payments between them. The IOU in this closed reserve system is called Federal funds, or, more simply, "reserves".

The poll came in 70% in favor of the statement being true. Let me explain why I disagree (also happy to discover any flaws in my own understanding):

The Fed is effectively a bank for banks. It replaced private clearinghouses after the Federal Reserve Act of 1913.

Four reasons the $2.5m fee txn was not money-laundering
@ekryski @OaktreeInv @lawmaster @zhusu Four, after all the attention this is getting, does it really seem like a good way to you to transfer money secretly? üôÑ
@ekryski @OaktreeInv @lawmaster @zhusu Third, the txn was mined by a large public pool full of public hashpower. The pool also immediately agreed to refund the transaction.

@ekryski @OaktreeInv @lawmaster @zhusu Second, once your txn is mined, you can't expect other miners to simply build on your txn but that they reorganize the block and take the fee themselves. Transferring money via fee is always a terrible idea, since any miner can fight for it - even after you have mined it.

@ekryski @OaktreeInv @lawmaster @zhusu First, you don't even need to publish the txn to the network. You can just mine it, and then other miners only learn about it once it's in the mempool. Containing it at a level where few people use it would be more than enough. How many people in this community would consider that a success for Bitcoin?
@phil_geiger @unchainedcap @parkeralewis Gold hasn't been "eradicated or killed" as a physical element, yet it is largely demonetized and the world runs on a fiat standard.

@phil_geiger @unchainedcap @parkeralewis We should agree on the same definition of a successful ban. If Bitcoin adoption is contained at a low level, and it's cumbersome and expensive to use, that seems like a success to me?
@phil_geiger @unchainedcap @parkeralewis That said, even if I decide to hold onto 10% of my coins for a rainy day, how do you think this benefits Bitcoin adoption?

@daddystaxxxsats @phil_geiger @unchainedcap @parkeralewis Not "countries" as in "all the people". It typically assumes there is a class that benefits disproportionally from the existence of the fiat system and wants to keep it alive.

(I don't subscribe strongly to one group or the other)

@phil_geiger @unchainedcap @parkeralewis The high-level answer is yes. It's not worth it for me to take the risk.

The low-level answer depends on the reward (do I need to send money internationally? do I live in a hyperinflating country?) as well as the cost (what's the likelihood and punishment of getting caught?)
@phil_geiger @unchainedcap @parkeralewis But also, if you assume countries lose no matter what, it's simply not a prisoner's dilemma anymore (which is a game with clearly defined properties).

@phil_geiger @unchainedcap @parkeralewis The text doesn't acknowledge that Bitcoin can be banned if all countries coordinate to do it. That's problematic for several reasons. For one, there are no arguments given. There is no empirical evidence, either (it has never been tried before)

@phil_geiger @unchainedcap @parkeralewis First, I agree that a prisoner's dilemma is the correct way of thinking about this. All countries collectively would be better off if they banned Bitcoin. But the more some countries ban it, the more others can win by defecting. Hence the "ban" equilibrium is unstable.

@phil_geiger @unchainedcap @parkeralewis We have seen uncoordinated bans fail (depending on how you define "fail", it was certainly successful in keeping adoption low), but to my knowledge, we have zero empirical evidence on coordinated ban attempts.
@unchainedcap I fail to see how this is a prisoner's dilemma. Why make a payoff table if even when countries successfully cooperate you flat-out assume a ban would fail? https://t.co/1VUF9yxsPW

@MichaelDunwort1 Exactly! I'm arguing that blockchains are not magically different from that. The only reason rules are harder to change in some blockchains is that automated rule enforcement and self custody make it easier for the majority to be intolerant. That sums up my thesis.

@MichaelDunwort1 All good, I appreciate the exchange :) not sure that we even disagree on much. I didn‚Äôt mean to say that all users have an equal voice in the article. Even very large economic actors like exchanges can be part of the tolerant majority (and most of them are most of the time).
@MichaelDunwort1 It seems to me that just passively holding Bitcoin and not pushing for any changes (or forking) is the most economically rational course for most people?
@MichaelDunwort1 My point is the rules and the economic motivations of actors are tightly intertwined. When users see an economic benefit to changing the rules, they will do so.

@MichaelDunwort1 That‚Äôs a romantic view, but the goals/rules of a system can‚Äôt defend themselves. They are an emergent property of many people using the same implementation. If people accept different implementations, the rules can change.
@RainDogDance Let me rephrase. There was a large special interest group against bigger blocks as well as an intolerant majority.

@RainDogDance I don‚Äôt think there was a significant smaller-block fraction back then. The opposing special interest group wanted to preserve the status quo, hence we wouldn‚Äôt expect a breakout below 1mb. Change was mostly not prevented by that, though, but a sufficiently-intolerant majority.

@RainDogDance @JeremyRubin You can review a change for years, but if the (significant) cost of adopting it outweighs the benefit it still won‚Äôt be adopted. The only way is to ride on an even more beneficial proposal, or bundle together with many less significant ones.
@MichaelDunwort1 I agree with that view. Users are not == users. What matters is their economic relevance to the system.

@RainDogDance On a high level:
* all changes must be pushed by special interest groups
* intolerance of the majority exists on a gradient - the more intolerant, the harder changes are *in general*
* hence, there is a vast space of changes that are positive, but not positive enough.

@RainDogDance yup, I clarified that. I think there are significant informal barriers to changing Bitcoin that discourage the steps you describe in the first place (getting to that formal implementation stage)
@MichaelDunwort1 I'm thinking about users of a particular system. Anyone who interfaces with it in any way. Most people don't participate in governance unless the stakes are really high
@muellerberndt the reason is all the cost incurred on the majority by these changes. The more people used custodians the lower these costs on the majority would be.

@muellerberndt Yes, intolerance of the majority exists on a gradient. The more intolerant it is, the larger special interest groups need to be. It's super hard nowadays to get any consensus change into Bitcoin, even ones that have decent support (OPcodes for LN, CTV...)
@muellerberndt The third diagram describes the optimal state for a system that tries to be difficult to change by design. It achieves this by making it easy for the majority to be intolerant

@muellerberndt There are different degrees of capture. It's harder for a special interest group to change the rules of Bitcoin (compared to other systems), but it's easier for some groups to block the proposals of others.
@muellerberndt actually, the third diagram is supposed to show how governance in Bitcoin (more so than Ethereum) is supposed to work https://t.co/xSTkPzpJ8W

@odtorson @nic__carter @hugohanoi so if billions worth of mining hardware mine blocks today, obviously you can't "easily" reverse these blocks later. you need to dedicate the same amount of hashpower to it or a smaller amount hashpower for a longer period of time.

@odtorson @nic__carter @hugohanoi what's firmly wrong is "you can rewrite history at little cost". if someone spent 100 hashes (made-up number, just to demonstrate) to make a block, you need to make 101 hashes to replace it with something else.

@odtorson @nic__carter @hugohanoi okay, but what are you saying here? that miners can rewrite the chain? that rewriting the chain gets more attractive when there are no block rewards? that both seems very uncontroversial

@nlebowitz1 @observantape @nic__carter @hugohanoi after 100 blocks coinbase rewards would disappear. any descendants of these coins would also disappear. in summary, a lot more people will be affected
@odtorson @nic__carter @hugohanoi no, not at all. but to replace the existing chain you need to make a chain with more cumulative work.
@odtorson @nic__carter @hugohanoi so if hashpower stays the same, a block that took 10 minutes to make will also take 10 minutes to replace
@observantape @nic__carter @hugohanoi but the benefit wears off pretty fast after 100 or so blocks. reorgs deeper than that would most likely be invalidated by users
@observantape @nic__carter @hugohanoi yes.
@odtorson @nic__carter @hugohanoi old blocks will cost as much to undo then as they cost now (measured in hashes). only the hardware gets better. block reward is unrelated

How frequently do miners update their block template in practice?

The process of mining is typically described as 
1. making a block template
2. repeatedly hashing the blockheader while shuffling through nonces
3. compare blockheader hash to target
4. if below target, publish the block. if above target, continue from step 2

* borrows USD against one home to build another.

Lending always creates leverage.

@lex_node @mhluongo @BitcoinErrorLog @udiWertheimer @MrHodl @evankaloudis @YousTof @fold_app @wlrvs In his quote, Rune simply describes the following trade
* someone borrows Dai against ETH, sells the Dai for more ETH. The result is a leveraged long position on ETH/Dai (proxy for ETH/USD)

@lex_node @mhluongo @BitcoinErrorLog @udiWertheimer @MrHodl @evankaloudis @YousTof @fold_app @wlrvs If the borrower defaults on the loan, the bank‚Äôs liabilities are now unbacked, so it must seize the collateral per the contractual agreement. In Maker, the bank seizes what‚Äôs in the vault (e.g. ether). In meatspace, the bank seizes your home, your business, our your future income

@lex_node @mhluongo @BitcoinErrorLog @udiWertheimer @MrHodl @evankaloudis @YousTof @fold_app @wlrvs Back to the borrower, who sells the money to buy something else (no one borrows money to hold it). Can be a new car, a new machine for her business, but she can also put it in the stock market.

@lex_node @mhluongo @BitcoinErrorLog @udiWertheimer @MrHodl @evankaloudis @YousTof @fold_app @wlrvs But instead of encumbering the asset in a smart contract, the traditional bank encumbers it in a legal contract. That‚Äôs possible because legal contracts can be enforced in meatspace, but not on a blockchain.

- business equity
- personal equity

a very simple explanation for why I see negative interest rates as the logical option *given the Fed's mandate of price stability against the CPI*

whether that's a good mandate or not is a different story.

@SimpleJ09349924 @nlw now the key insight is that fiat money works the exact same way. holders of fiat money are the long side, borrowers are the short side. since the dollar currently misses its inflation target, you want to make longs pay shorts - and the correct tool is negative interest rates.

@SimpleJ09349924 @nlw it does that until demand has balanced enough that the price returns to the target. when the swap trades below the target, it does the opposite. it charges the negative rate to shorts and pays it to longs.

@SimpleJ09349924 @nlw the funding mechanism observes the prices of the swap and the target (e.g. BTCUSD on a spot exchange). when it's higher than spot, it decides that there's currently too much demand from the long side. so it starts charging longs a negative interest rate and pays it to shorts.

@SimpleJ09349924 @nlw it's easier to understand by looking at the crypto exchange example. there are so-called "perpetual swaps", futures contracts that never settle. the only way that they track the underlying price is because of a "funding mechanism".

So the goal of the group would be to get better at some of the things I described above together. Share great articles, talk about them on a meta level, and draw conclusions from them. Also possibly critique each other‚Äôs articles.

So one idea I pursue is to collect article templates. Extremely high level concepts for how to structure an article, how you build a point. So you can more easily start from an existing frame and then only fill it with color, you don‚Äôt have to craft a new frame every time.

As a side effect, I wouldn‚Äôt have to be so scared that I won‚Äôt ‚Äúfeel it‚Äù if I stop writing now, and then I‚Äôd exhaust myself a lot less.  I want to be able to write on auto-pilot and for it to be still decent.

So I‚Äôm not looking to improve my A-game, but actually my C-game. Optimally, writing would become more of a mechanical craft than an art where you need to be ‚Äúfeel it‚Äù constantly. Optimally, I‚Äôd be able to write even when motivation or focus or inspiration are not at top level.

I‚Äôm looking to make a writer‚Äôs group on Telegram.üìù

My selfish goal is to improve as a writer. I have a ton of ideas, but am too unstructured to really benefit from them. Most of the days I can‚Äôt write, and then some days I completely exhaust myself writing 10 pages.

@3Bayless @jp_koning @QWQiao @Hasu Yes, but look at the consequence. People will start to withdraw money from banks and instead hold huge sums in cash (as seen in Switzerland, where banks have massive vaults in the mountains full of cash).
This is, in two tweets, the thesis for bitcoin that the largest macro investors subscribe to.

This insight is so important because it challenges the idea that ‚Äútime can never go backward‚Äù. Most people see fiat money as strictly superior than money of phases 1 and 2. They don‚Äôt acknowledge that other societies have been in phase 3 before, before returning to phase 1.

Dalio‚Äôs arguments in here are not new, but he does a great job as usual synthesizing them into a coherent thesis. The main idea is that money has its own mega cycle, and we are currenty somewhere in phase 3 (credit money), before returning to phase 1 (hard money)

@evoskuil @RussHarben @SGBarbour Can‚Äôt believe we have to chew through this but ofc my statement is not tautological.
Anything that can be defined as a game and written down as a decision matrix is not tautological. I merely assume
- who are the players
- their choices
- payoffs
- choice model (e.g. rationality)
@evoskuil @RussHarben @SGBarbour Yeah, these are secret assumptions that feed into any model. I assumed rationality. What else do you suggest?
@evoskuil @RussHarben @SGBarbour What does that mean?

@evoskuil @RussHarben @SGBarbour You can absolutely prove a statement that contains assumptions. 

‚ÄúAssuming that the defender has more hashpower, even if it is turned off right now, the attacker should never attack.‚Äù

@evoskuil @RussHarben @SGBarbour The attacker can never succeed as long as the defender has more hashpower. It doesn‚Äôt matter that the hashpower is turned on, it only matters that he turns it on when poked. The attacker has only costs, no revenue, hence -EV, hence never attacks. QED

@evoskuil @RussHarben @SGBarbour It can rationally be financed by an expectation that revenue goes up after censorship ends, even without any txn fees. @evoskuil @RussHarben @SGBarbour As long as the monopoly miner has majority hashrate *in theory* he can keep his machines turned off. Only use as much as is needed to stay >50%. He can then add more when needed to orphan attacker‚Äôs chain. Then turn off again.
Correct strategy for attackers is not to attack.

@evoskuil @RussHarben @SGBarbour I‚Äôll give you a concrete example. After a monopoly miner has not built on _any_ block that wasn‚Äôt their own for a full month, other miners eventually give up. Now the monopoly miner slowly reduces their hashrate by 10% per month.

The main insight here is that miners need to make a chain that satisfies the demands of the market. If they do, the market rewards them for it. If they don‚Äôt, the market punishes them. And the larger the block reward overall, the more miners have to lose from such misbehavior.

The value of block rewards, and that includes the subsidy, is set by the market. Qualities like censorship-resistance also go into the price in some shape or form. In a world where miners actively censor transactions, I assure you that the price would be a lot lower as a result.

You‚Äôre assuming miners care only about BTC rewards, but that assumption is wrong. Miners, of course, also care about the $ value of these rewards. As long as censorship makes BTC worth less, they lose money from censorship even in a subsidy-only world.

At some point a new equilibrium is found where crypto systems are adopted at the fringes (maybe 5-10% market share), the whole financial system is more robust, and the total intermediation tax is lower.

Crypto systems will keep growing as long as people are unhappy with the intermediation tax. To stem the outflow, incumbents will get their house in order and the tax will go down until it is lower than the switching cost.

My personal hope is that the mere existence of permissionless and censorship-resistant alternatives can check that intermediation tax. Thanks to competition, the intermediated systems would retain their efficiency but the tax would go down.

I agree that intermediated systems are efficient and will persist. However, their discretionary nature also makes them vulnerable to some of the illnesses @nic__carter describes in his article. These weigh like an ‚Äúintermediation tax‚Äù on the original efficiency gains.

@valkenburgh @nic__carter @NYcryptolawyer By using the Bitcoin protocol, you exchange freedoms (e.g. to take the property of others) for the right to not have your property taken from you by others.

@valkenburgh @nic__carter @NYcryptolawyer Regarding this tweetüëáThe point is not to have rights against the protocol. A protocol is a rulebook for how humans interact *with each other* (what you can and can't do.)

@valkenburgh @nic__carter @NYcryptolawyer I wrote the longer-form version of that argument down here https://t.co/OjHGjGuRDU

@valkenburgh @nic__carter @NYcryptolawyer we are granted all kinds of rights by private institutions in exchange for certain freedoms, but we are not used to applying this to property rights (which are almost always granted by the state.) But the Bitcoin network can grant property rights independent of the state.

@valkenburgh @nic__carter @NYcryptolawyer I think "rights" is the correct context. Rights are created by restricting freedoms. Humans invent institutions to do that. In some institutions participation is voluntary (e.g. the market), in others it's mandatory (e.g. the legal system or the state)

I think we should focus on bailouts as the source of moral hazard here rather than dividends vs stock buybacks. Bailouts totally change the way companies should be run, because they no longer need to prepare for industry-wide shocks like this. It punishes prudence.

In practice, they express them with stock buybacks because the tax system actively encourages it. But if stock buybacks are banned, we can still get the same result with dividends. Especially if we lower taxes on dividends (which seems to be in the cards)

I also wonder about this. Yes, companies for some time now have preferred to return capital to their shareholders rather than invest it. They are also highly levered because debt is cheap. But can't companies express the same preferences with dividends if they wanted to?

@RpprNght The bottom line is that it's terribly costly to leave orders in the book that are not likely to be taken, and taken at discount to the real outcome at all. So it doesn't happen.

@RpprNght By posting "yes" orders you incur costs:
1) cost of capital for the duration of the order
2) cost of the free option (if someone has better info than you they can take the bet, otherwise not).
3) cost of monitoring the distribution of outcomes, otherwise you become the fish

@least_nathan The DSR is Dai's risk-free rate because you cannot be liquidated if you hold it. All other systems where Dai can be lent have more risk. So the DSR necessarily drives rates in all of Defi. And as we can see, it is entirely the result of the price of Dai and nothing else.
@least_nathan 2) increase demand to hold Dai (so there's more capacity for borrowers to open new CDPs, again Dai must trade at ~1$). They do it by paying people to hold the coin. That's the DSR!

@fnietom @peterktodd In the case of inflation, there's no need to lower the block size.

Without inflation, it makes sense to lower the blocksize to remove any excess supply of blockspace. The idea is the market favors low wait times + high fees over very high wait times + low fees.

@pierre_rochard @fnietom @peterktodd That sounds similar to arguing a $20 lock can only succeed in the marketplace if the $10 lock is utterly broken. In practice, it just needs to be unilaterally better on a dimension that people care about, e.g. long-term sustainability.

@fnietom @peterktodd The market doesn't automatically support the lowest inflation coin, it supports the lowest inflation coin that works. People would realize that if they thought about price inflation instead of supply inflation. Cost is not everything & the cheapest product does not always win.

@YangTerrence @timoncc @BlockDebate @C_Bendiksen The bottom line that, of course, we'd prefer Bitcoin mining to be as politically distributed as possible. I just tried to lay out why Bitcoin is not automatically broken without that.

@YangTerrence @timoncc @BlockDebate @C_Bendiksen If the US or China set their mind to destroying Bitcoin, then there's little that could be done about that, yes. @timoncc @BlockDebate @C_Bendiksen I don't see where "non-rational" attackers are considered or why that matters.

@timoncc @BlockDebate @C_Bendiksen In other words, Bitcoin's goal is to implement honesty as the dominant equilibrium even if we assume a single actor controls all the hashpower, bribes are possible, and do so in a robust way (meaning a large external force is required to push the system into an inferior state)

@timoncc @BlockDebate @C_Bendiksen 2) a miner has >50% hashpower. In that case, we hope the dominant miners' incentive is still to follow Nakamoto Consensus. This is what the incentive (the block reward) entices because an attacker would incur opportunity costs by destroying the system.

@timoncc @BlockDebate @C_Bendiksen Bitcoin has two layers of defense if you will.
1) every miner has at most ~10% (or insert any other number here) hashpower. In that case, most attacks are impossible to succeed because of race-condition.

@timoncc @BlockDebate @C_Bendiksen Rationality merely means miners are self-interested ("greedy"). A rational miner would attack if it is more profitable to do so. Satoshi clearly assumes that in the whitepaper: https://t.co/eJxU9yB4dN

@killerstorm @kallerosenbaum pay miners X*

@killerstorm @kallerosenbaum A vulnerability is simply something that prevents the protocol from working in its intended way. If the protocol is supposed to miners X, but users can circumvent X, that's a vulnerability.

Of course, the mistake is not with users, but with the flawed design of the protocol.

@maqstik @coindesk By using a rationality assumption, you force yourself to create the conditions that entice that majority to be honest.

Second, honest majority assumptions work for closed systems, not open systems (not vice versa), because there you control who can be a BP in the first place.

@maqstik @coindesk I think that's two misconceptions. First, it is stronger than a mere honesty assumption, because the honesty assumption does not concern itself with how actors arrive at a certain type (honest/byzantine). You're just making it easy for yourself by assuming an honest majority.

@maqstik @coindesk Good point. So far only networks have been attacked that a) are very small, and b) allow repurposable hardware (usually even rented, not bought.) The result in both cases is that miners need no long-term commitment to the network, giving them the power without the cost.

@Saul2GoodmanEsq @coindesk The logic applies to governments the same way it applies to the private sector. If the Chinese government decided to confiscate all mining ops tomorrow, they still incur an opportunity cost.

@ManuelPolavieja Anyway, after thinking about this some, I'm not really bent on making the definition fit anymore. There's clearly an exchange agreement between users and miners. Miners can also financially damage users (as well as vice versa! e.g. users can fire miners by changing PoW)

@ManuelPolavieja However, I don't think it's fair to say that Bitcoin users have no counterparty risk in their relationship with miners (as a group) because no legal agreement exists between them. The legal agreement is replaced by a mechanism that can be used without identity or legal fallback.

@ManuelPolavieja I'm tempted to think this is owed to the fact that a) verbal agreements are contracts as well, and b) all exchanges in traditional systems are secured by explicit legal contracts (even if most people never read those)
@ManuelPolavieja To be fair, Investopedia also defines "counterparty risk" as "the likelihood or probability that one of those involved in a transaction might default on its contractual obligation."

@ManuelPolavieja Both sources further say that contracts can be used to secure the transactions between different counterparties, by defining their respective rights and obligations. This is optional.

@ManuelPolavieja Investopedia: "In any instances where a general contract is met or an exchange agreement takes place, one party would be considered the counterparty, or the parties are counterparties to each other."

@ManuelPolavieja How about you show me a definition of "counterparty" that adheres to your description? Meanwhile:

@ManuelPolavieja Why do you need liability to exist? For many transactions, my counterparty might be legally liable, but a breach is uneconomic to punish. So is he actually liable then in practice? Does it mean he's not my counterparty if I can't punish breaches?

@ManuelPolavieja I think there's a clear expectation for miners to behave in a certain way. They are (currently) paid for it by the protocol. So there's an economic transaction there, between users and miners?

Gauntlet's @TarunChitra has modeled their system under extreme market conditions. I believe all DeFi projects should subject themselves to stress tests like this.

His paper is worth a read as an introduction to Compound's inner workings and the risks users should be aware of.

Compound controls these risks with some key parameters, e.g. the collateral factor (how much borrowers can withdraw in relation to their collateral) and the size of the liquidation incentive.

Setting the right parameters is a tightwalk between capital efficiency and stability.

This mechanism has a couple risks, namely that 
1) shocks to market prices could send collateral value plummeting;
2) loss of liquidity in an external market makes liquidation unprofitable; or
3) cascades of liquidations impact external market prices (deflationary spiral)

.@CompoundFinance relies on a mechanism that sells risky debts to liquidators at a discount. That discount is the liquidation incentive. The liquidators buy the debt and repay it on behalf of customers.

This is essential for the system to stay solvent (assets > liabilities)

@devilninja777 @pete_rizzo_ @0xstark Price increases don't really help with security, because they increase both the security budget and the attack incentive at the same time.
@joonian @pete_rizzo_ @0xstark block reward dropping too low (in BTC terms) is the cause; a low opportunity cause is the first-order effect; eventual attacks on Bitcoin would be second-order effects

@pete_rizzo_ @0xstark As a result, you can't get into a position where miners can no longer afford to mine. That's not the problem here. The problem is that future rewards could go so low that an attacker no longer incurs a large opportunity cost by attacking Bitcoin.

@pete_rizzo_ @0xstark You're looking at it backward. The mining reward doesn't have to pay the cost of mining ops. If the block reward was $1, miners would spend up to $1 to earn it. So their expenses always track the value of the block reward anyway (also referred to as MC=MR)
@antiprosynth @0xstark I'm not worried about anything else.
@pete_rizzo_ @0xstark Users initially bought bitcoin with electricity, now they buy it with USD. Not sure how that ties into the topic of decreasing block subsidy
@pete_rizzo_ @0xstark It's a problem because an attacker has to burn less and less money *relative* to Bitcoin's network value.
@pete_rizzo_ @0xstark All values in $ here. If the $ price of $BTC increases, the $ network value increases, and the $ security budget increases.

@pete_rizzo_ @0xstark This is a massively important property of Bitcoin and one of the reasons it has stayed secure over 11 years. Problems emerge if the security budget, in BTC, falls below a critical threshold (full disclaimer: we don't know where that threshold is.)

@pete_rizzo_ @0xstark Our point is, it doesn't matter for security if the market moves up, down, or sideways. The security budget, consisting of future block rewards, scales with the network value.

Example: $BTC doubles, network value doubles, security budget doubles
@pete_rizzo_ @0xstark I don't assume anything about that. Sounds like a completely tangential issue.
@pete_rizzo_ @0xstark Large in BTC. Otherwise, you get into a situation where Bitcoin's security budget detaches further and further from the value of the network it is supposed to secure.
@pete_rizzo_ @0xstark So basically it's instrumental to Bitcoin's long-term robustness that the miner incentive is sufficiently large. Experts disagree just how large.

@pete_rizzo_ @0xstark It means Bitcoin is secure only when miners make more money from honesty than attacking. As the honest incentive (the block reward) declines, Bitcoin's assurances weaken, which hurts demand, which further lowers the incentive, which weakens assurances, which hurts demand, etc.

I wrote down my thoughts on security X derivatives.

@juthica If the market has to learn how to price risk from miners, we also want to give it an opportunity to do so. For example, if hedging introduced additional risks then risk buyers should demand increasingly large premiums.

@juthica Summing up, I'm strongly in favor of building derivatives markets for Bitcoin. If miners want this, it's inevitable anyway. And if their existence makes Bitcoin more fragile, we want this information sooner rather than later (when more people might rely on it for their savings)

@juthica If risk buyers and risk sellers (miners) agree on a "correct" mining behavior, and the buyer can monitor that behavior, and the buyer can enforce breaches of contract... that would be optimal.

@juthica 2) derivatives don't make risk disappear, they only transfer it to someone else. If miners sold options, someone else now has their alignment to the network. Globally there's still the same amount of capital dedicated to BTC, only there's a principal-agent problem now.

@juthica But is all *all else held constant* ever realistic? Probably not. I see at least two forces that pull in the opposite (pro-security) direction. 
1) price volatility is a cost to miners. Can a fully-hedged mining industry support higher hashrate than one that isn't hedged at all?

@juthica We haven't looked much at derivatives markets in our existing analyses, so take the following thoughts with a grain of salt. One thing we can say with certainty is that *all else held constant* hedging BTC exposure -> less alignment -> less security.

@juthica I don't think the fact that miners can hedge their alignment to Bitcoin with options should make you question your efforts. If miners are willing to pay for that service, someone will offer it to them. Bitcoin has to be secure in spite of liquid derivatives markets.

Virtually all attacks on cryptocurrencies to date have tried to double-spend. Two reasons that could change in the future:

1) as the sum of future block rewards decreases, the cost of attack goes down
2) as Bitcoin becomes more important, the incentive to sabotage goes up

All in all, Purge attacks probably don‚Äôt constitute a bigger risk than other known forms of sabotage attacks, but represent an interesting spin where the attacker specifically targets the pre-coordination of defenders.

2. Its second wall of defense is the strength of Bitcoin‚Äôs pre-coordination in the face of attack. 

A leaderless group of people can carry out their defense more easily if the right response is self-evident to most people.

üëÜ this is what the attacker wants to disrupt

How to defend against this? Purge attacks are similar to all other forms of sabotage attacks in this case.

1. Bitcoin‚Äôs first wall of defense is the sum of its future block rewards. It represents the amount of money an attacker has to burn to sabotage the network.

A Purge attack is a form of sabotage, aiming to undermine trust in Bitcoin's assurances, e.g. the future finality of transactions.

üí°We named it after the dystopian movie The Purge, where all crime is legal for one night every year.

When is a Purge attack a good idea?

We are unlikely to see it if the attacker himself wants to double-spend. The more people he affects, the more he increases the range and likelihood of triggering a violent response (e.g. PoW change)

Double-spends of unconfirmed transactions are made possible by transaction replacement. For that reason, zero-confirmation transactions are widely regarded as unsafe.üëª

In a Purge attack, an attacker retroactively applies a zero-conf policy to the entire network.
Once in the mempools, anyone with a minimum of technical knowledge or access to public tools can opportunistically double-spend their transactions back to themselves. https://t.co/WvK01iV1RB

In a Purge attack, an attacker replaces blocks full of transactions with empty blocks.

As a result, previously confirmed transactions are sent back into the mempools (the "waiting area" for Bitcoin transactions.)

This week in our @DeribitExchange Insight: 

Introducing Purge attacks, a practical form of sabotage that tries to create coordination disincentives among Bitcoin users.

Key takeaways below! üëá

In Bitcoin, property rights are enforced with public-key cryptography. Anyone can read the database (to know they've been paid), and write access is auctioned to a permissionless set called miners.

It should be clear that gold-backed stablecoins offer zero innovation in that regard. Only a centralized party can write and read that ledger. Bitcoin has many problems, but at least it represents meaningful innovation in read+write access.
As a result, all money devolves into "someone else's ledger", including gold-backed currency. The main difference is in who is allowed to write and read the ledger.

But gold, in practice, is not that useful as money. It's expensive to secure, transfer, assay, hard to divide, etc. That's why the endgame for gold is always in central custody, which ultimately threatens its hardness.

Governments have no incentive to return to gold except temporarily to stabilize a struggling fiat currency. If hard money ever becomes popular again, I think people will have adopted it in a bottom-up instead of top-down fashion.
Gold-backed stablecoins inherit 100% of the problems of previous gold-backed currencies. Users have to trust a central party not to debase the currency or otherwise exert control over it.

@paul_btc @gaborgurbacs yes, the problem is not debt but the debt's long-term return. that's why credit card debt is uniformly seen as bad: it almost never pays off. on the other hand, debt used for investment that ultimately leads to increased GDP has a positive return.
@gaborgurbacs https://t.co/EWgpj7ZazA

@gaborgurbacs banks don't create money. they merely transform an illiquid asset (the borrower's future ability to repay) into a liquid one (bank deposits). you can't prevent this from happening in a free market, because transforming your future ability to replay is the *optimal thing to do*

@gaborgurbacs some good reads on the topic
(1) https://t.co/1eTCf8XQQT
(2) https://t.co/eTZIZhC6Vl
(3) https://t.co/QBiPlPBWFw

@gaborgurbacs since the bottleneck for debt is the ability to make interest payments, it doesn't make sense to measure the total amount of debt a country has. what matters is the debt-to-GDP ratio, which describes the real ability of a country to match its future liabilities.

@pierre_rochard @MEKhoko I'm still confused about what your caveat even is. Before we run into the wrong direction, how does Moore's law contradict Satoshi/the EMH?
@nic__carter But back then there was no secondary market. If you wanted BTC, you had to mine it. In that scenario, the energy cost of BTC *was* the market price.

@nic__carter I don't think he misapplied it here. It depends what is larger, the primary market or the secondary market. Today miners are merely producers and the secondary market is the consumer. So the secondary market dictates what the price of BTC is and the primary market simply follows.

@CapitalistDog1 Of course, but that's very different from your initial quote "the price of any commodity tends to gravitate toward the production cost." 

The production cost of Bitcoin follows the price by design. The same number of coins is auctioned to miners every 10 minutes.

@pierre_rochard @MEKhoko Imagine I announce that I'll eat muffin tomorrow. Do I gain weight today? Of course not. 

But the moment there is a market where people bet on my weight, today's price will reflect future information.

@CapitalistDog1 Aha, got you now. "The price of any commodity tends to gravitate toward the production cost" is of course only true as long as production is profitable. If it's unprofitable, more and more producers will shut down until the remaining production cost again matches the price.
@pierre_rochard @MEKhoko What does Moore's law have to do with this?
@pierre_rochard @MEKhoko Sure, that's why stocks fall on poor guidance (the official prediction of near-future P&L)
@CapitalistDog1 The hashrate *is* halved due to halving. Just not at the time of halving, but before and after over a longer period of time, because mining ops take some time to spin up & shut down.

@nic__carter The cost to mine BTC has always followed the demand to hold it. Only these coins never entered the secondary market because anyone who wanted to own Bitcoin could mine it with their own computer. So the primary market and secondary market were initially one and then separated. https://t.co/yxpNb82q7G
@CapitalistDog1 So in practice, if miners know new supply will halve at date x, they invest less money compared to a hypothetical scenario where the new supply doesn't halve

@CapitalistDog1 Exactly. It doesn't halve hashrate at the time of halving, but it halves the total investment into mining over a longer period of time. The reason is that mining ops take a long time to spin up (6-12mo) and a long time to pay off.
@CapitalistDog1 Bitcoin is not a commodity because of the difficulty adjustment. Producers can't ramp up or slow to production to make more or less of it.

@Mario_Gibney @La__Cuen Seigniorage is also not a problem in Bitcoin, because the permissionless nature of mining allows anyone to compete for it. Free entry + competition drives down the margin to a minimum. But without that margin, there would be no mining, no security, and no Bitcoin.

@Mario_Gibney @La__Cuen Seigniorage is the difference between 1) the cost of producing a unit of money, and 2) the revenue from selling it. That describes *exactly* the profit margin of miners. You could hardly ask for a more fitting example.

@ecurrencyhodler @La__Cuen If security reasons (e.g. from hashpower concentration) were cited, my argument is these were already secondary to considerations about seigniorage, e.g. "these evil ASICs have made my commodity hardware useless. I deserve to be able to mine from home!"
@ecurrencyhodler @La__Cuen Their network itself is the open-source infrastructure in this case.
@nic__carter @La__Cuen and then over time margins become smaller and smaller.

@nic__carter @La__Cuen I think the profit margin of miners fits exactly the definition of seigniorage. I would agree that this margin is largest when a network launches and *someone* has to provide security (good example is your new launch model that's supposed to favor developers over of Bitmain)
@La__Cuen Bitcoin hasn't changed its PoW so far, though some people who have lobbied for it in the past
@La__Cuen ProgPoW is a battle for seigniorage.

@La__Cuen There's a ton of lobbying in PoW chains if you're willing to look. Almost every crypto that has changed PoW has not done so far security reasons but to financially benefit certain groups of people over others.

@La__Cuen I think Vitalik's point is that people who oppose seigniorage to fund OSS development under the guise that "all seigniorage is evil" ignore that every system has seigniorage, including Bitcoin.

@La__Cuen It's provoking but not entirely wrong. Hardware & energy producers have profited immensely from the rise of PoW based cryptocurrency, which is a form of seigniorage. Of course, a premine doesn't solve this at all unless it pays for security.
