(9) we can reframe the security equation from
security threshold > MEV
to
security threshold > transaction volume * % at-risk transactions

We still need to consider off-chain MEV, but that about summarizes the relationship between safe tx volume and the block reward.
@least_nathan @joekelly100 @_prestwich I forked off into my own little thread, apologies https://t.co/KOYFSLN6gC
(8) even though every individual transaction may be small to medium-sized, collectively these users expose each other to risk via double-spend.

(7) the ability to monetize, as @_prestwich points out, depends not just on your own acceptance policy, but that of everyone else. general rule! the more people accept payments without legal recourse, the more can an attacker steal in a single attack.

(6) so the short answer is yes - the safe transaction volume is limited by the block reward. what's not clear is the ratio between transaction volume and MEV. it depends on the attacker's ability to monetize the attack, primarily via double-spends.
(5) this is where we circle around to your question @least_nathan. every transaction generates MEV, but it's unclear how much. @_prestwich touched on this in his subthread https://t.co/bvau05X4wa

(3) the security threshold tells us how much an attacker has to extract before breaking even on the attack. we group these benefits under the umbrella term MEV.

(4) MEV includes value generated both on-chain (e.g. from theft), and off-chain (e.g. from sabotage or censorship)

(1) the block reward establishes the cost of attack (not the budget requirement, but permanent loss for the attacker)

(2) the cost of attack determines how much an attacker has to extract before breaking even: we call this the "security threshold"

@RichardRed0x So less-than-100% of votes can withdraw 100% of the available funds *per month*. Not a big difference.
What's the lesson from this thread? On further inspection, arcane-sounding concepts like DAOs often turn out to be the combination of existing primitives. In this case MuSig wallets + voting.

The downside to using a stateless chain like Bitcoin is that the number of pre-signed tx required grows exponentially with every additional member to the wallet. So it can only support setups with a small number of participants.

You can also do this on Bitcoin by depositing into a MuSig wallet and create pre-signed transactions. Any member can publish their transaction to withdraw their share. This is how LN channels work! Then to spend, you require n/n participants to sign the transaction.

@RichardRed0x There's actually a big difference between what I describe and the Decred DAO. By giving members the ability to unilaterally withdraw their own share, the majority can never bully the minority. In Decred, less-than-100% of voters can withdraw 100% of the funds.

When we think about DAOs in these abstract terms of "some people manage a wallet together, they can add very specific spending conditions, etc." they seem very promising. I can imagine we'll see millions of these set up in the future.

Interestingly, this common purpose vehicle was the original vision of the ICO. Unfortunately, the most important feature - giving tokenholders control over the ICO funds - was scrapped for legal reasons.

When people put 100 BTC in a DAO, and that DAO issues a governance/equity token to control the spending of the BTC stash, then that token seems only one step removed from holding a BTC private key directly. It's really just a MuSig wallet with a voting feature.

@nicksdjohnson @Marcolevarato The bottom line: ASICs aren't the only form of MAD that exists, but a very strong one. And while Satoshi didn't predict ASICs, he implicitly described MAD (or a weaker form thereof) in the whitepaper: " [...] undermine the system and the validity of his own wealth"

@nicksdjohnson @Marcolevarato "He ought to find it more profitable to play by the rules, such rules that favour him with more new coins than everyone else combined, than to undermine the system and the validity of his own wealth."

@nicksdjohnson @Marcolevarato "The incentive may help encourage nodes to stay honest. If a greedy attacker is able to assemble more CPU power than all the honest nodes, he would have to choose between using it to defraud people by stealing back his payments, or using it to generate new coins."

@nicksdjohnson @Marcolevarato Satoshi didn't write a ton about Bitcoin's incentive model and probably wasn't 100% sure if it would work out. But his intuition was that the system can only be secure if honest mining is more profitable than attacking:
@nicksdjohnson @Marcolevarato Indeed. I think it was fortunate that Bitcoin a) started with a very high block reward, and b) it was hard to profit from attacking the network for the first few years.

@C_Bendiksen @MichaelNov_KV @CoinSharesCo @_prestwich @bcmakes We recently performed an analysis on Vertcoin with the new, simplified formula:
https://t.co/9dGpygb6ag

@C_Bendiksen @MichaelNov_KV @CoinSharesCo @_prestwich @bcmakes MP (miner punishment) describes the value miners would lose as a side-effect of attacking the chain (e.g. when their NAV falls)

It's a function of MC (the total miner commitment/investment) * punishment factor (price reaction to the attack)

@C_Bendiksen @MichaelNov_KV @CoinSharesCo @_prestwich @bcmakes Yeah, we can make extremely good guesses about MC! 
btw, we simplified the formula further to MP/MEV (which basically says risk/reward)

@C_Bendiksen @MichaelNov_KV @CoinSharesCo @_prestwich @bcmakes This relationship is independent of the BTCUSD price, given that price changes affect both sides of the equation equally. 

If BTCUSD doubles, MP doubles, but MEV rises as well (does it double? We don't know. But Trump or Xi Ping would have not commented on Bitcoin at $50m mcap)

@C_Bendiksen @MichaelNov_KV @CoinSharesCo @_prestwich @bcmakes To speculate on overall security, we really have to put the two in relation with each other: What is the reward for an attacker compared to the risk (of permanent loss?)

@C_Bendiksen @MichaelNov_KV @CoinSharesCo @_prestwich @bcmakes We have to make very rough guesses for MEV (the reward for the attacker) and MP (the risk/cost for the attacker.) 
MP, in particular, depends a lot on how the bitcoin price reacts to attacks.

@JaEsf Liquid is no more built on the Bitcoin basechain than it is built on the EOS basechain. Which means, not at all. It's an entirely separate entity.

@JaEsf Not that I'm aware of. Do you know how these sidechains work? A group of trusted parties accepts token deposits and withdrawals, similar to an exchange, and maintains a ledger. The security properties of that ledger depend entirely on the quality of the group members.

Centrally issued tokens benefit from public blockchains because of existing userbase + exchange infrastructure (incl. wallets) that lower settlement and transaction costs. None of which Liquid/RSK has.

Hence, it doesn't make any sense to issue tokens on a BTC sidechain today.

That doesn't mean Liquid/RSK won't play a role in the future. Empirically, ~5m $BTC sit on exchanges. So security concerns are not the bottleneck. When fees on Bitcoin pass $10 again, we might see a burst of interest to hold and transfer $BTC on the various sidechains.

Refreshing thread, where Pieter cleans up the popular misconception that Liquid and RSK somehow inherit the security properties of the Bitcoin base chain.

If you want to issue a centralized token, do it on Ethereum. It already has users, wallets,  exchanges, tooling...

Bottom line, the Maker team should probably increase the delay time even when they think the MKR supply is sufficiently concentrated in the hands of good actors. The market should be aware that, even before this analysis, Maker has not been "non-custodial" or "trustless."

This is not inherently bad. Bitcoin and Ethereum themselves are secured by economic incentives. Oftentimes in crypto, we can't make it impossible to do bad thing X. But we can associate a cost to X and hope that's enough.

What *shouldn't* be surprising about this:

-  51% of MKR holders always had the power to do whatever they want, including stealing all the money. 
- Maker is a custodial system. User funds are secured by economic incentives not to act maliciously.

- There is protection against malicious minority changes from MKR holders in the form of a governance delay. During this period, other holders can force the system into global settlement. 
- The problem is that this governance delay is currently set to 0 seconds.

What should be surprising about this: 

- A relatively small amount of MKR (80k) is staked on the current governance contract. That means an attacker with 80k MKR could swap in a different contract at any time.

An analysis by @MicahZoltu shows MKR holders could steal all user deposits if they vote in a new executive contract (basically change the rules of Maker)

Decentralized applications will have bigger risks, but these risks can be worth it. Notably, rumor has it that many large exchanges will add full KYC in 2020. What then?

In traditional finance, we limit this potential with legal recourse: almost any transaction can be rolled back, and both parties and applications can be made liable to make redemption payments out of their own pocket.

At the bottom line, we should ask how much money can be permanently lost from malicious oracles. In Bitcoin, we limit this potential with cryptography: the network ensures that miners can't print new coins, can't spend other people's coins, etc.

In PoW, we pay block producers for a signal which block to add to our local chaintip. Occasionally, they may fail to send the signal, or send a malicious one. I think there are some interest parallels there as well to the oracle problem

I noticed people tend to fall in one of three groups

1) "Bitcoin doesn't need much higher fees (it is secured by X instead)"

2) "Bitcoin needs much higher fees, but I'm optimistic we'll get there"

3) "Bitcoin needs much higher fees, and this is a really hard problem"

I noticed my first tweet warrants further clarification. 

A paradox is a seemingly self-contradictory statement. It does not imply the contradiction actually exists under all conditions!

Indeed, if fee revenue (in BTC!) rises by ~50-100x, the paradox is resolved.

To prevent this, it's not enough to hope for a rising BTCUSD price. What matters for security is the relationship between MEV* and MR**.  That relationship stays largely constant no matter the price.

*miner-extractable value
**miner revenue

Bitcoin's social contract contains a paradox: 

- supply capped at 21m units (and no "cheats" like demurrage) 
- strong assurances in terms of tx finality and censorship res.

In practice, assurances are strong *because* miner revenue is high.

The demand from the Treasury under a redeemable gold standard may be gone, but other sources are still intact: taxes, global trade, and forex reserves, to give just three examples. They all continue to back the Dollar to this day.

3) Forex Reserves

Same as other countries, the US holds large amounts of forex reserves. These can be sold into the open market to generate additional demand for USD if necessary, further supporting its value. 77% of the US reserves are in gold, south of 8,100 metric tons.

2) Oil & Global Trade 

The US actively ensure that commodities like oil and much of global trade are settled exclusively with USD, e.g. by protecting global trade routes. When this demand is challenged, the response can be forceful (e.g., Iraq war 2003).

1) Taxes & the US economy

A lot of this demand comes from the USG itself, as every year people have to sell it USD in return for extinguishing their tax obligation.
@pierre_rochard Buffet doesn't actually hold cash, it's just shorthand for bonds. These bonds throw off interest, hence are productive assets, not unproductive.

@ManuelPolavieja @acrual To be precise, planting it is only of the inputs to a mature apple tree, it also needs sunlight, water, etc. Collectively they create the tree and hence its terminal value

@ManuelPolavieja @acrual The value of the apple-tree is created by planting it. That's not speculation, unless one also thinks that the terminal value of the tree is currently underpriced by the market.

Buys the tree later with the goal to sell it at a higher price is speculation.

@ManuelPolavieja @acrual I need to think about how to record it, but the idea that Bitcoin going from $1 to $9k creates an equivalent amount of value is absurd to me. If anything, all forms of money are in their own zero-sum competition with each other.
@ManuelPolavieja @acrual The important point is the buyer at $9k has nothing to do with the seller at $1. They both are your counterparties - not each other's.

@ManuelPolavieja @acrual "We don't need to talk about a game's value to the players because it must already be positive for those who play and already be negative for those who don't play."

@ManuelPolavieja @acrual Your example is not speculation. Speculation is a bet on future price movements in real or financial assets. However the bet ends, one player's win is the other's loss.

@ManuelPolavieja @acrual If a game creates externalities but is zero-sum for the players themselves, the game designer (usually the state) can change the rules of the game to convert externalities into actual payoffs to discourage (pollution), or encourage the particular behavior (speculation.)
@ManuelPolavieja @acrual Externalities are not payoffs to the players themselves, that's how they get their name. Pollution is another such example.
@ManuelPolavieja @acrual As I said, if the value doesn't accrue to speculators but outside the game, it can still be zero-sum.

@bergealex4 @EmpireaiIo @MrHodl @hexlib @edixonve @zndtoshi @RainDogDance It's really not that hard. If you own x% of the hashrate, this hashrate has a value no matter what you intend to do with it, and you can cash it out by a) selling it, or b) using it. 

Whether you burn it or not, the commitment is real, and destroying it incurs a real cost.

@bergealex4 @EmpireaiIo @MrHodl @hexlib @edixonve @zndtoshi @RainDogDance If you buy the hardware with the intention to burn it, it costs you the same (or more) as if you wanted to mine honestly: ~660k BTC.

@MrHodl @cyberamine12 @zndtoshi @RainDogDance Yes, for this example we used 60% hashrate, but you can plug in anything you want. The less commitment (yet-to-mine coins) he owns for the attack, the better for the attacker.

@cyberamine12 @MrHodl @zndtoshi @RainDogDance In our paper, we assumed 1) and 2) to solve for 3) to show that the attack-value would have to be ~21,000 BTC for an attack to be profitable at today's miner revenue.

@cyberamine12 @MrHodl @zndtoshi @RainDogDance In this case, you want to solve for 1) "how high does miner commitment need to be for EV(honest) > EV(attack)?" So you only need to plugin your rough assumptions for 2) punishment and 3) attack-value.

@cyberamine12 @MrHodl @zndtoshi @RainDogDance It depends on many factors and no one can give you a concrete number. 
1) How many (yet-to-mine) coins do miners own (commitment)? 
2) How willing are users to sell coins (punishment)? 
3) How much could value can be gained from an attack (double-spends, censorship, sabotage...)?

@NoUserName36 @angela_walch The blockchain has currently ~250 GB, which every new node needs to download to compute the UTXO set. That's called the initial block download (IBD).

https://t.co/aJJ4d712Xu can tell you how much bandwidth a full node uses after that to stay in sync.

@NoUserName36 @angela_walch Keep in mind the size of the blockchain increases as well. It's not clear that hardware and bandwidth increase fast enough to keep up, let alone warrant future increases.

So no, Bitcoin's L1 can not scale anytime soon. Not while retaining the same assurances for users.

@NoUserName36 @angela_walch Capable of handling what? The primary goal of the blocksize cap is to keep validation costs for users low. A blockchain that can't be validated is useless. That's why blocks can't be larger than ~2.3 MB right now, and some argue it should be lower.

@NoUserName36 @angela_walch The key insight is that whenever supply > demand, fees are effectively zero. The more supply you have, the more demand you need to generate any fees at all. That should be intuitive; the on-chain scaling supporters ultimately wanted more supply so fees go back down.

@antiprosynth @RyanSAdams Yes, they are not willing to hold the asset because the excess security is not worth the cost. The asset is *too secure*. That shows why cost must be considered when evaluating monetary policy.

@RyanSAdams @PeterRizun Dumbing something down is a noble goal, so I meant no offense there. I agree that monetary policy is the single largest driver of security, that was the main lesson from our paper. Only we should add that it has to deliver that security at a cost that users are willing to pay.

@SavantSpecter @RyanSAdams @PeterRizun You address an interesting problem. The system designers have to make a conscious decision which users the system should serve and which it shouldn't serve. A system that tries to serve everyone ends up serving no one.

@RyanSAdams @PeterRizun Maybe, but when you dumb it down into one specific goal like "maximizing security" we lose so much precision that it's equally useless. All properties of a system work in tandem to make the system useful for users in a lasting way.
@RyanSAdams @PeterRizun What value do you hope to get from using it? It is that, but across many people.

@PeterRizun @RyanSAdams Exactly! The goal of monetary policy is the same as of the system as a whole: maximizing value for its users. "Security" is how well it can deliver that value under adversarial conditions.
@RyanSAdams This should be in line with intuition. All things equal, the security of any system increases with how much you spend on it.

@RyanSAdams It depends on how you define security. If we see security as the maximum MEV (and hence economic activity) a system can tolerate relative to its network value, then security increases linearly with MR.
@maynardbarthol1 @NicolasDorier @lopp They are not identical. If "being in the market" is +EV, then lump sum maximizes your investment per unit of time and hence your EV.

@NicolasDorier @lopp When we say "beat", it's important to define what our goal is. DCA can beat lump sum in "maximizing return while minimizing 50%+ drawbacks." In raw EV it can indeed never beat it, but raw EV is also almost never the correct yardstick in investing.

@RyanSAdams While I liked that newsletter overall, I disagree with that statement. If the mandate was to maximally secure the network, why not double the supply every year in perpetuity for maximum security? The reason is we want a good middle ground between security and use-value.

What practices do _you_ really like in podcasts and what practices do you want to see less off?

What podcasts (crypto or not) execute these practices perfectly?

@DZack23 @laurashin If your definition of "favorite" is different from "most-consumed", then I found that understanding why you use something so much helps you consume it more consciously & with greater appreciation going forward.

@DZack23 @laurashin I was genuinely surprised because when people ask me straight-up, "what are your favorite podcasts?", it wouldn't have been in my top 3. Sometimes it takes active introspection to reveal my true preferences.

Overall, these are great podcasts for one because Laura is a great host that checks her ego at the door and doesn't pretend she gets something when she doesn't. And second, her show has enough of a moat that she can ask uncomfortable questions and still get high-profile guests.

There are other reasons, e.g. that most other podcasts are too long and force you to skip the first 30 minutes of ever-repeating "what's your background" questions instead of giving a 60-sec summary and then jumping right into the action.

This frustrates me because when the host didn't get it there's a good chance I, the listener, didn't get it either. But whether to not look bad, or not make the guest look bad, hosts typically don't follow up and push for better explanations until it clicks. This happens _a ton_.

The second reason is that @laurashin keeps asking until she understood. I can't remember how many times I was annoyed with other shows where a guest gives an insufficient explanation of a concept or thing that happened, and it's 100% obvious the host didn't get it.

Hence, any podcast without a significant moat in reach either gets mediocre guests and good interviews or good guests and mediocre interviews. Good guests and good interviews require that the value of the podcast to the guest is high even when questions are hard.

When too much leverage resides with the guests, interviews will be worse because guests can select easy conversations over hard ones. Who wants to face hard questions on-air when there are ten other podcasts with the same audience?

That a host should see eye-to-eye with the guest seems obvious, so why don't other crypto podcasts do this as much? I think the answer lies in the relatively high supply of podcasts, and relatively low supply of interesting guests.

First, she asks uncomfortable questions. It's hard to do this delicately, and sometimes you get a crazy show like EP78 with Dominic Williams of Dfinity who practically collapsed from her (modest!) pushback. But overall, modest pushback makes shows much better.

A good example is the dawning realization that every network competes to be money and has to offer qualifies of good money (which means adding strong restrictions to what users are allowed to do that are very similar to Bitcoin's).

That doesn't mean a competitor can't disrupt Bitcoin with much better technology. It can, but it has to do it on Bitcoin's terms, by offering the same social contract for people to opt into. The values of bitcoiners shape everything in this space.

The individual's path to Bitcoin isn't about learning how the tech works or downloading a wallet. That's merely the last meter. It's about questioning your own values and how you think human societies should be organized, the role of voice vs exit etc.
Imagine still thinking in 2019 that crypto is primarily technology. It's a new social contract, a way of organizing human group activities.

More and more people will come to this realization that @nic__carter briliantly expressed in his latest article "A most peaceful revolution"

Technology is just a tiny part of the socioeconomic movement we call "Bitcoin", the visible tip of a gigantic iceberg.

Or, it can (iii) throw away all but the most recent history, as it was only needed to compute the current chainstate. 

(3) Pruning the chain is recommended for users with little disk-space, and listening (not seeding) is recommended for users with little bandwidth.

(2) After the IBD (initial block download), a node has several choices:
It can keep the entire blockchain on hand to (i) perform analytics or (ii) seed blocks to the rest of the network and provide other nodes with a way to download the blockchain.

There's a common misconception that all full nodes store the entire blockchain. The reality is a bit more complex:

(1) A new node downloads the entire chain only to trustlessly compute the current UTXO set: what coins exist and who owns them (also called the chainstate).

@oscpacey If you call Bitcoin a ponzi scheme, please explain at what stage leaving becomes more attractive than staying for existing participants.

To wrap around to the initial question, a potential investor should ask himself whether a mature Bitcoin system is genuinely useful to him and others.

If the answer to that is positive, there's no reason to expect the system to unwind as more people join.

Because Bitcoin becomes more useful the later in the adoption cycle we are, there is never a point where the marginal buyer can lose from adopting it. Only the value for the marginal buyer will come less from people finding it useful later than from himself finding it useful now. https://t.co/0seFNsYggr

What was seen as speculative value during the earlier adoption stages was merely the discounted use-value of later stages. In the beginning, Bitcoin had no use-value. In the end, Bitcoin has only use-value.
The EV of a pyramid scheme decreases the later we are in the adoption cycle. But the EV of a network good like money increases, as it becomes more useful the more people own it.

The question seems reasonable: Once Bitcoin is widely adopted, the future value from speculation will indeed be zero. But that ignores half the picture - where has that speculative value gone? And does it mean that earlier buyer now have an incentive to sell?

A common question that precoiners have is, "How do you know it's not too late to buy bitcoin now?"

They still assume Bitcoin follows the value/adoption curve of a pyramid scheme - a system that needs to sustain itself with new buyers and collapses if those ever run out.

@MaciekLaskus @udiWertheimer No, Protestantism is a clean hard-fork from Catholicism. I was speaking from the perspective of the individual user.

@MaciekLaskus @udiWertheimer The utility of Bitcoin depends even more on other users than religions. In religion, you can follow some of the rules and ignore others. If someone locally breaks a rule in Bitcoin, they are out. That makes disagreements in Bitcoin more dangerous, but also less common.
@udiWertheimer Bonus round: If I trust someone to do something against their own interest, that is not called trust, that's superstition

@udiWertheimer I have to trust that I know someone's utility function. I have to trust that they know it themselves. I then have to trust they actually do what's in their best interest. Humans are irrational.
@joonian Old men will be important, but they can't change Bitcoin on their own. They can only highlight Schelling points and have users evaluate their proposals based on actual merit.

Other system: You have to trust all the time. In case of failure, five old men in a room will fix it.

Bitcoin: You have to trust very little under normal operations. In case of failure, everyone in the network needs to agree how to fix it.

There's a widespread denial about Bitcoin's trust model, even though the above view is supported by factual Bitcoin history. There is no reason to be ashamed, either: While Bitcoin is still a trusted system, it requires LESS TRUST LESS OFTEN than alternative systems.

The periods of social consensus are so pivotal that we care a lot about where others stand, and invest a lot of energy so people who stood against us before (e.g. NYAG supporters) lose their voice in future social consensus.

Bitcoin is not a system that requires NO TRUST between participants, nor would that be desirable. So far, humans had to to intervene every two years, either to fix a dangerous bug, undo damages from a bug, or push back against an internal takeover.

Real talk: We are vigilant about the values of other bitcoiners because we have to TRUST they will stand with us when shit hits the fan and some dangerous force is threatening to destroy Bitcoin's social contract.

The Lightning Network is a network of payment channels and the idea is that it compresses many Bitcoin transactions into a smaller number of base-layer transactions without compromising on security.

@dailyBTCmemes Payment channels are one example. Two parties in a channel exchange pre-signed transactions without broadcasting them to the network until either party wants to close the channel.

@spreekaway Yeah, I just added a third tweet. As physical constraints change, systems can also become more (or less!) scalable. Hardware and internet speeds advance very slowly however, and it's not clear that they advances faster than the size of the UTXO set as well as IBD data.

Scaling blockchains is a game of constraints. There are fundamental design constraints (everyone must be able to validate) and physical constraints (e.g. hardware quality). The second category is a hard wall and Bitcoin operates very close to it.

If you can't make transactions smaller, you have to restrict the validator set. That's where 99% of altcoin "innovation" is happening. Unfortunately, that constraint from the first tweet, "where anyone can validate cheaply", is the *only thing* that makes blockchains valuable.

Bitcoin is easily the most scalable network *where anyone can cheaply validate*. You cannot contest it either, because Bitcoin transactions are as small as they can be. We can only increase their economic density per byte by bundling tx offchain and settling them occasionally.
@DTAPCAP HH is very similar to Libra. Same architecture, same strengths & weaknesses.
@CoveringDelta @RainDogDance @RyanMilb @RaoulGMI Awesome!

@CoveringDelta @RainDogDance @RyanMilb @RaoulGMI There's no insurance premium needed (only enough to afford the fees of one onchain transaction!)

and no confidence crises possible, because we don't trust each other at all in the first place. We only transact with full collateral and settle immediately.

@CoveringDelta @RainDogDance @RyanMilb @RaoulGMI Maybe an example helps the best. Imagine we open a channel with 100 sat each. So the channel is 100/100. We both get a presigned tx to redeem at 100/100. 

Now I send you 50 and we update the channel balance to 50/150. Presigned tx are also updated.

@CoveringDelta @RyanMilb @RainDogDance @RaoulGMI To reiterate, if your CP in a channel gets hacked he cannot steal your money. He can only force liquidation of the channel (take the collateralized contract and redeem it onchain) and then you both get what you own, you only lose the channel.

@CoveringDelta @RainDogDance @RyanMilb @RaoulGMI As long as both sides of a channel are happy with the arrangement and the channel is sufficiently collateralized, they can keep transacting contracts instead of onchain bitcoin. What makes this trustless is the ability for either party to unilaterally cash out to the main chain.

@CoveringDelta @RainDogDance @RyanMilb @RaoulGMI They are though. You can broadcast a valid presigned transactions to turn it into onchain bitcoin immediately. All that can stop you at this point is miner censorship, and that is true for an onchain transaction as well.
@CoveringDelta @RainDogDance @RyanMilb @RaoulGMI If you understand this architecture you will see that trust is absolutely not the issue - it is all the collateral required to make this work.

@CoveringDelta @RainDogDance @RyanMilb @RaoulGMI What makes this more scalable is that it's very cheap to exchange these contracts back and forth *as long as all parties in that contract are sufficiently collateralized*.

@CoveringDelta @RainDogDance @RyanMilb @RaoulGMI There is no credit in LN, all transactions are settled immediately between parties - though, and that's the crucial part, not on the base chain but by exchanging trustless contracts (the presigned tx) that either party can take and redeem at the base chain at any time.

@CoveringDelta @RainDogDance @RaoulGMI It scales worse than trust-based systems where an intermediary (or federation of intermediaries) manages the ledger, which is ok. We can have many different Bitcoin payment systems with different trust/scalability tradeoffs. LN is very faithful to the on-chain trust model.
@RainDogDance @CoveringDelta @RaoulGMI And the presigned transaction always reflects the current state of the channel (who owns how much)

@RainDogDance @CoveringDelta @RaoulGMI The key insight @CoveringDelta is that a valid presigned transaction is 99.9% as good as an on-chain transaction, because either party can unilaterally take the presigned transaction and turn it into an onchain transaction.
@CoveringDelta @RainDogDance @RaoulGMI They are secure because the two parties exchange presigned transactions. Either of them can unilaterally close the channel and finalize the current state.

That's not a critique of present-day Ethereum. Just an observation why using @bitstein's talk to claim the moral highground is dismissive of Ethereum's own past.

Bitcoin Twitter plays it rough, but it's also worth noting that during the boom this toxic little community was the only one not giving newbies like me the impression that the laws of economics don't apply in this new paradigm.

Maybe the success of their own ICO made Ethereum leaders blind to the consequences of this model catching on, but I don't know if that's necessarily a better a view than greed. I'd love to read a post-mortem on what went wrong in 2017-18, but doubt we're going to get one.

What bothers many is how the highest ranks of Ethereum endorsed the ICO as a concept -even though the incentives behind it are fundamentally broken- and how that support benefited them financially, while retail investors lost billions (maybe dozens of billions) of dollars.

The reason that this smells so hypocritical isn't that scammers ICOed on Ethereum. Plenty of unethical people use Bitcoin as well. In a permissionless system, you have to accept that you can't control what other people do with it.

@comcentrate1 That cost of mixing you mention is itself a result of supply and demand, since tainted coins compete to mingle with untainted coins to create plausible deniability. The more competition, the more untainted coins can charge.
The natural buyer of tainted coins is whoever can clean them. For traditional currency this is a huge industry, estimated at 5% of global GDP, better known as money laundering.
Discount for tainted coins is a function of supply (how many coins get tainted) and demand (how many coins can get untainted) in a given timeframe.

As with all disruptive technologies, ask yourself what they compete with. Cryptocurrencies can compete with fiat money, but private pension plans only compete with *other private pension plans* - not the public pensions which most people cannot opt-out of.

In most places, the only ways to opt-out of public pensions are 1) self-employment and 2) living off capital gains (no income). Rational people should accept a significant premium in order to gain access to private pension alternatives.

@QWQiao https://t.co/rtSMfyg7TY

So conceptually, winning punters get banned because no one wants to take the other side of their bets. Now in p2p markets, people don't get banned for winning already. And decentralized markets, so far, are always p2p. So this problem is in no way resolved by decentralization.

Plenty of people commenting "but punters get banned from betting sites all the time for winning". 
Yes, that's correct, but those are bucket shops where it's the house taking the other side, and the house has every right to stop taking the other side if they expect to lose.

@MyCousinVitalik Nah, players actually burn through their deposits all the time. When a casino stops the marketing machine they don't just "stop growing", they run out of new deposits incredibly fast.

@BrettRichey Yeah, that's a fair point. The biggest bets I've heard of happen p2p. Bitcoin 2of3 (or 3 of 4) MuSig can actually help with escrowing here. Two bettors deposit the stake, then you have 1-2 trusted oracles who need to sign after the bet is resolved.

@MyCousinVitalik As a smart gambler you quickly learn to love rake, because 80%+ of it is invested back into acquiring new customers, who end up being your customers also. Decentralized products lack this kind of perpetual liquidity creation. That's a huge downside, not an upside.

@BrettRichey If you have a p2p market in trad finance, you don't get banned for winning. That only happens only when you bet (and win routinely) against the house. My point is let's compare apples and apples (p2p and p2p) not apples an oranges (p2p and bucket shops).
@etiennebru @guesser No, what for? I'm actually curious. What can I bet on that I can't do at existing betting sites?

@BrettRichey The oracle problem is not actually a big deal when you're an actual business. You can try to stiff customers with fake outcomes, but then word gets around and customers simply leave. The incentives are properly aligned towards honesty since outcomes are easily verifiable.
@BrettRichey Why? You can have centralized companies like Binance or BitMEX. Put them on top of decentralized payment rails so you're not easily shut out from the financial system.

Coming from the gambling world, I've met some of the biggest punters you can possibly imagine. People who bet huge on politics, sports, etc. None of them give a shit about prediction markets. The existing regulated betting markets have them 100% covered.

As for decentralized prediction markets I continue to be pessimistic. I've yet to meet someone who actually wants to use these things, and even with demand, I fail to understand why they need to be decentralized beyond the underlying payment rails.

If I was pro ETH and contra EDG, I would look for any contract I can find that can signal at no cost, including all the other DAO contracts.

Then market dump all EDG and surpress their price.

As a comparison, imagine that BCH just forked off from Bitcoin. EDG/Polkadot are effectively a social fork of Ethereum. 

Every BTC holder gets a BCH. 

But instead of market-selling it to drive down the price (market governance), pro-BTC people start burning their BCH.

This is a wasted opportunity. Instead of exposing the immoral launch of an Ethereum competitor, he may even have helped them by locking some of the 90% "non-premined" supply, making the remaining Edgeware/Parity pre-mine more valuable.

This strategy would have been entirely by the rules and shown that the EDG Lockdrop is a scheme for Polkadot and Parity to cash in on their frozen funds. 

Unfortunately, he decided to burn the private key, making the EDG unspendable and the whole Signal moot.

Johnson's signal would have given him a large EDG allocation at launch. He could even claim a 3 month Lock - or be denied by Edgeware "governance", putting an even worse light on them.

Then he could market dump to punish EDG and donate the proceeds to a good cause.

Enter @nicksdjohnson, an Ethereum developer who controls the account that deployed the DAO withdrawal contract back in the day. He realized that his contract, among others, can also signal (and possibly lock?) in the Edgeware Lockdrop.

Now, there's certainly a lot to criticize. The ability for contract voters to signal (and even lock) is basically a pre-mine for Polkadot and Parity, and a hidden one at that. What better way to demonstrate this than by exploiting the rules yourself?

Edgeware even went a step further and added a clause that turn's Polkadot's Signal into a 3month Lock for the purpose of the allocation (for an even bigger bonus). Who is allowed to convert is decided on a "case by case basis", whatever that means. https://t.co/aTLiJ58kcQ

The vote (and EIP) fell through, but the same method made it into Edgeware. Same as the carbon vote earlier, the Lockdrop gives special rights to contract creators, allowing Polkadot to signal with the funds locked by Parity.

The EIP came with a carbon vote, which drew a lot of criticism because it allowed contract creators to vote for the funds stored in these contracts. As a result, Polkadot was able to vote with 306k ETH they didn't control.
https://t.co/rghkRixhWj
Now, you can imagine Polkadot/Parity would love to get these funds back. in 2018, Parity wrote EIP-999 (Ethereum's counterpart to BIPs), a suggestion to unfreeze the funds.

Edgeware is the first parachain launching on Polkadot, which is developed by Parity. If you remember, over 500k ETH are frozen on Ethereum due to a bug in the Parity MuSig implementation (over 300k ETH of which belong to Polkadot).

Edgeware (a soon-to-launch Ethereum competitor) is running a Lockdrop event, a form of proof-of-work where you lock up ETH for 3 to 12 months (thus incurring opportunity cost) and in return receive EDG tokens at launch.

@MikeMcDonald89 Coins in Bitcoin belong not to legal identities, they belong to private keys. No private keys, no coins, unless social consensus explicitly says otherwise.
@MikeMcDonald89 Miners can't give these BTC to anyone because they don't control them. Any such change requires a hard fork and thus voluntary social consensus by users.
@udiWertheimer @CarpeNoctom I don't disagree, should have just used a less controversial example. Any double spend is accepted by Bitcoin consensus.
@C1aranMurray @danheld Agree, everything is driven by economic incentives.

@CarpeNoctom Not going to get into this discussion with you again. I only used that term because we need to distinguish between double-spends that are accepted by the social layer vs rejected. Binance thought what they did would be accepted, but it wasn't.

@bitcoinmystick What Binance thought about doing would have been legal in Bitcoin consensus. Full nodes would have automatically switched to their chain. Users threatened a hard fork (a manual rejection of the original chain) and that prevented Binance from pursuing further.

@bitcoinmystick Yes, it would have been a hard-fork. And there have been rollbacks in Bitcoin before: https://t.co/XeY4Yx0YdZ
It almost happened again last year with CVE-2018-17144

@CryptoSecundus @MihailoBjelic @khannib has since implemented live stats for these batching metrics:
https://t.co/vR8mlrjjQn

Nope. Many operations are legal in Bitcoin consensus that would be rejected by social consensus, e.g. double spends. When Binance suggested a friendly double-spend to disincentivize future hacks, there formed almost immediate social consensus to hard-fork Bitcoin in response.

@danheld In fact, I think Ethereum became immutable too fast by not undoing the Parity bug. It set back the development of a reliable MuSig by years because it showed to users and devs that the social layer doesn't have their back when something goes wrong.

@danheld Agree. That culture is cemented in the decision to use a blockchain + PoW in the first place. It should be clear that you don't beat bitcoin by becoming more immutable. Ethereum's shot was always moving and iterating faster. The DAO decision was entirely in line with that.

@danheld I look at it the other way. We don't decide something should be immutable. Immutability is an emergent label we give to properties that were historically hard to change.

An interesting implication is that it's meaningless to call something "immutable" that was never challenged.

@danheld The DAO was supposed to do X but did Y. Many didn't like Y, partially because Y lost them or people close to them a lot of money. Enough people felt strongly about undoing Y that the market (ppl who felt less strongly about X/Y) quickly converged on X-chain being more valuable.
@danheld Social consensus is whatever the social layer decides ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

No, blockchains simply automate social consensus discovery. If automation breaks down, the social layer must be able to reset or override the system. That's not a bug but a crucial part of the security model. Without it you become a slave to miners.

@joe_miller0 @hussmanjp Mining can be unintuitive. There are many crypto-native people who still call PoW "wasteful" today. I think they miss the point that MC->MR in any scheme, even if it seems cheaper or more useful at first. Think about what the USG spends to defend the USD's reserve status.

@hussmanjp In other words, as more money can be made from mining, more resources will be spent on mining. Proof-of-work is already the cheapest validation scheme possible, because it prevents rent-seeking. Miners spend exactly as much on validation as the market demands, not one bit more.

@hussmanjp If mining generates "useful" output other than native coins in a network (e.g. finding prime numbers), the value of this output would simply become a secondary block reward (boon) for miners. As the value of the block reward increases, miners spend more to get it. MC->MR.

Thus, it seems to me that every global company added as a validator doesn't make the network less fragile but more. These companies have little to win and a lot to lose from breaking local regulation. Thus, I expect them to overcomply everywhere.

We can deduce how Libra's validator set will develop in the future. When the majority of validators is reachable, it can prevent unreachable validators from joining the network. That works in PoW, but it's even easier in a consortium. Thus, the network can never decentralize.

Libra/Globalcoin turns this concept on its head and then takes it to the extreme. With a consortium of global companies, validators are not just known, but hyper-reachable. Globally operating companies, naturally, can be pressured globally.

Thus, we can think of validators as either unknown and unreachable, known and unreachable or known and reachable. In Bitcoin, some validators are known and some unknown. That's fine because the unknown validators keep the network working even as known validators are shut down.

If you are known, you can still be unreachable by operating from a regulation haven and offer your services world-wide. Important: Make sure to have no pressure points located outside of that jurisdiction. Think Chinese miners serving US customers or vice versa.

At the foundation of cryptocurrency is the ability to validate transactions anonymously. Why does this matter? Known validators can be pressured to comply with local regulation and censor all users and transactions that don't don't comply.

@doweig @nwoodfine I'm super bearish on real money gaming online, especially in the decentralized context. Botting is a prime example of a problem that can only be solved with trusted and permissioned systems instead of trustless and permissionless.

@doweig @nwoodfine For all these reasons, online gambling is dying a bit more every year. Or at least the larger, more anonymous player pools dry up and splinter into much smaller pools of people that trust each other not to cheat.

@doweig @nwoodfine The latter can range from reading your processes and memory to slightly moving around buttons on the screen or even just changing individual pixels. It's a constant cat-and-mouse game.

@doweig @nwoodfine Online casinos (which should be your idols here) attack the problem from both angles. They invent new games by adding more rules and, in particular, adding ever more randomness so skill edges disappear. And they build interfaces that discourage automation.

@doweig @nwoodfine Beyond the game space you want to consider the cost of automation. A bot that a human consults while playing is extremely easy to make. One that reads the game state and acts autonomously is harder.

@doweig @nwoodfine The size of the game space (imagine a decision tree) determines how hard a game is to solve. Connect4 is so tiny that no matter how you change the rules, it won't affect the ability to solve the game. So you might as well keep the original rules, or humans will play even worse.
@cantshutup_ @zhusu @coincenter The problem is already solved by what @zhusu described

@doweig @nwoodfine Rule changes only hurt bots when they increase the game space so much that creating bots becomes unprofitable. It has the inverse effect when the game space is so tiny that the rule change affects only the humans, not the bots.
@doweig @nwoodfine If anything the introduction of white pieces makes (proprietary) bots more profitable, because it drives the human player population further away from playing optimally.

@CryptoShark @hivedotone @ZLOK It's not censored, it's highly moderated. Reddit just doesn't scale without moderation. Blame the game, not the players.

@hivedotone Our input is highly curated and more useful. The underrated flipside is that our output is itself curated by people who see as positively. Thus our interactions on Twitter are so positive. It's a positive feedback loop.

@hivedotone One reason that Reddit karma is not effective for feed curation is its democratic (1 user 1 vote) nature. On Twitter, we can add weight to the opinion of people we love (follow + notification), respect (follow), accept (neutral), mildly (mute) or strongly dislike (block).
@hivedotone @B1tcoinChange Anything that benefits from manual curation, e.g. an entry point for beginners.
@B1tcoinChange @hivedotone If Reddit produces small communities, Twitter produces microcommunities with perfect interoperability.

@hivedotone One reason that no original information makes it to Reddit is the lack of social scalability, a result of the respective scaling solutions. Reddit has moderation and karma. Twitter has follow, retweet, like, mute and block. Twitter gets better with more users, Reddit gets worse.

@hivedotone Twitter is the public base layer of information and gossip on the internet. Anything newsworthy is shared and discussed here first. Eventually it disperses to higher curation layers like Reddit.

@hivedotone Reddit users prefer curation by community vs self-curation on Twitter. On Reddit, at most 1% of users produce all the content, others consume passively. On Twitter, all users chit-chat constantly.
@hivedotone You will get opposite results from asking this poll on Reddit vs Twitter. There isn't much overlap between the two communities.

Polo already wasn't very popular, but margin spot trading was one of their USPs. Now it's hard to see who will lend on their exchange going forward. To add insult to injury, they will most likely get sued by all the big lenders who took a haircut. Tough times ahead.

That Polo allowed someone to build such a massive position using this scheme and then not even prevented him from withdrawing is hard to forgive. All that regulation is worth nothing if you don't have basic risk management on your exchange.

Alternatively, he can do what @zhusu described and lever up one account with CLAMP collateral and then liquidate it with a second account. The real counterparty in this trade are again other lenders, who have to cover the losses incurred by the second account.

From that point, the attacker has several options. He could use his fake collateral to margin trade real pairs, like BTCUSD. These bets have an asymetrical risk profile: either he loses his worthless collateral, or wins real money.
By allowing a tiny illiquid shitcoin to be used as collateral, Polo allowed an attacker to washtrade this coin, CLAM, to any price he wants and drive up the value of his own fake collateral.
@StackinBits Yeah, they washtraded it up to increase the value of their fake collateral.
This is what happened on Poloniex. Use two accounts, try to get one indebted to the other, have Polo pay your winning acc by socializing the "loss" of the losing acc on everyone else.

In sum, these are the reasons I have committed myself to the private money space, which, I fully believe, will turn into one of the biggest and most powerful industries in the world. It is on us to shape what values that industry will be built on.

Soon, individuals can import their money directly via the internet without relying on the government-provided bottom layers at all. Combine that with digital goods and p2p services making up more and more of the world GDP, and we could see a democratization of trade and capital.

The biggest winners when all has been written will be the people in Emerging Markets. Local money has long been a layer-3 institution. Stable money needs stable property rights needs a stable monopoly on violence. But no more.

If private money allows people to dodge taxes at low risk, this behavior will eventually normalize. This may be the tipping point in the growth of government that causes a mean reversion. Thus, private money will further accelerate the rise of the individual over the collective.

This shift will produce winners and losers. One loser could be (supporters of) big government. The large governments we have today are only possible because a) seigniorage from inflation and b) control over the financial system encourages people to honestly report their income.

It's hard to wrap your head around how easy it is to participate in the Cambrian explosion of money, whether we end up with one large winner in the end or several medium-sized ones. Hell, Bitcoin was created by, at most, a small group of people that is still anonymous today.

We may be using different money in every shard and yet another money that is entirely trustless (bitcoin?) between them. The design space for money today is magnitudes greater than it has ever been, so history isn't really a guide for us.

The biggest friction might come in the fragmentation of the internet itself. In the same way that the unipolar world order and US-protected free trade are ending, the internet itself will almost certainly break into several shards between China, Russia, and the West.

Consolidation into one money assumes a world where custody and exchange are the biggest sources of friction for money. In reality, the friction just changes its form. The walled gardens of supranational networks like Facebook will replace the walled gardens of national economies.

Much has been written about money being a winner-take-all or -most market, but I don't really believe in that. As the costs of storing different monies as well as exchanging between them decreases, consumers automatically put more focus on other properties.

These changes in money could move the world closer to utopia or dystopia, depending on what your values are. The only outcome that seems certain today is that money will fragment as more and more producers enter the market and increase the options for consumers manyfold.

While in most of history local governments have issued money, many private producers will be able to compete in the future. Networks like Bitcoin are constructed from the ground up to resist, while private firms like Facebook are effectively sovereign to nation-states.

Money is ripe for a paradigm shift, but the direction of that shift is still undecided. There are currently forces pulling into several directions, with the extreme ends being hyper-control of money (MMT) and removal of all control of money (Bitcoin.)

I'm excited about Erlay, a near-magnitude improvement for Bitcoin's networking layer. If you want to learn more, @bitcoinoptech also has a fantastic explainer in this week's newsletter.

Channels per node
Number of nodes
All data taken from https://t.co/4RKkR0AuzD https://t.co/dCzXXlvcV5

Direct channels between users who don't transact a ton with each other are not sustainable, because they need more on-chain transactions, not less. Thus, channels are an expense. The goal should be "the best possible connectivity with the least number of channels per node."

The goal of a payment channel network isn't to have as many channels as possible, but simply for every node to be able to transact with every other node. Especially early on that connectivity was bad, so users had to open channels directly with each other.

The number of LN channels has stalled, but the number of nodes (which is arguably more important to measure adoption) has continued to increase. I am no expert on LN, but I think a decreasing number of channels per node can also be a positive sign for the network.

So two things can be true at the same time: 

1) Discrimination exists in Bitcoin just like everywhere else.

2) If you realyl want to make it here, you can make it anyway. It's easy to forget how much of an improvement that is on almost every other industry out there.

When pseudonomy is tolerated, the ability to discriminate someone based on race/gender, or even things that have nothing to do with those like size/voice/looks, is _greatly_ diminished. You become fungible with other people. All that matters are your ideas and conduct.

I won't argue there is no discrimation here. I'm just reporting that as someone who went pseudonymous from the start, it never hurt my ability to make friends with people, become a full member of this community or even to find a job.
After 1.5 years in crypto, I still haven't been asked me for my race and gender. How very inconsiderate of you.

Another way to visualize the questions:

1. Of all ways to store and transfer wealth, why private money?
‚¨áÔ∏è
2. Of all private monies, why cryptocurrency?
‚¨áÔ∏è
3. Of all cryptocurrencies, why Bitcoin?
@morcosa @MarkFriedenbach @kanzure What security assumptions are being violated?
@libovness Should be, 100%. Bitcoin is a sociopolitical movement enabled by a breakthrough in technology. "Culture" is part of the moat, because it prevents the market from creating substitute goods.
@galenmoore Yup. Denying this is a great way to immediately lose all credibility with intelligent investors.

The most important step is to build common ground with your conversation partner. 

With O'Leary, it would have been to acknowledge the great qualities of the USD. The angle is then to present BTC as a way to offer similar qualities to people without access to USD.

3. What is the moat? A massive headstart in a winner-takes-all or winner-takes-most market. It leads so much in terms of network effects, liquidity, and community that it may be impossible for other coins at this point to be the 10x better required to catch up.
2. What is the innovation? An open p2p network that replicates the ledger on computers around the world. Designed from the ground up to survive under the most adversarial conditions.

1. What is the market? People without access to strong currencies like the USD (for political or geographic reasons.) People without trusted third parties that allow them to reliably transfer and store wealth.

In my opinion the smarter investors want to know three things before they acknowledge BTC as non-scam:

1. The market 
2. the innovation
3. the moat.
‚¨áÔ∏è

Today, I don't personally know a single Bitcoiner who goes to Consensus. I know around 40 who go to MCC. I like Coindesk, they have some great reporters (like @La__Cuen), but I think they have an image problem today. Hope they can turn it around next year.

Even though there are other promising projects besides Bitcoin, Bitcoin is now king again. Coindesk didn't see it coming and failed to rebrand into a more Bitcoin-focused journal and conference. TheBlock scooped up a lot of readers from the Bitcoin space.

The prohibitively high ticket prices are another mistake. They create short-term revenue, but over the long term lead to inverse customer selection. Who can afford to go to Consensus? People with something to sell. You can never turn your conference into a trade show.

For the last two years, the Consensus conference has become connected with ICOs and being fairly loose with accepting speakers and sponsors. This has, again, not changed (Tron as head sponsor, anyone?).

But if we do, it would be premature to assume it will look like a gold standard 2.0

We should be careful not to attribute outcomes we like to free-market competition and ones we don't like to government intervention. 

In reality, we prob haven't come close to a free market for money and never might; controlling it is simply too valuable.

People in this space often cite the gold standard as the resting state of the market for money. According to them, this outcome is somehow naturally emergent, ignoring the fact that gold itself won over silver on the back of massive government intervention.

My point is, we don't actually know what happens when the market structure changes as much as it might change for money in the decades to come. We haven't seen the free market that we always talk about.

There are also plenty of reasons why a free mkt for money can change this:

Today,

1. exchanging and holding int. ccy is highly regulated

2. all coins have similar properties and security models

3. increases in demand don't reward holders but producers

@allenf32 Totally agree, Bitcoin won't replace governments. It will compete with them for some assurances they provide: protect savings, facilitate trade, access to capital etc. 

Countries that offer that on their own will be totally fine.

@allenf32 SWIFT may look like a privately-owned company but it's controlled by the US government. Anyone competing with SWIFT either has to bow or resist, there's no middle ground. So the adverserial mindset is necessary for Bitcoin to compete on its own terms.
@bquittem Love that framing

@matbalez For the next few decades, I don't see that happening. 

The trend goes towards nationalism everywhere. Globalization and free trade are reversing, the internet could soon split into 3-4 internets, rising anti-immigration sentiments etc.

@matbalez I think the nation-state solves many demands of human existence, not just defense but also esoteric stuff like a shared history and sense of belonging. I wouldn't be particularly worried about them.

@matbalez Bitcoin doesn't replace nation-states. It competes with them for some (of the many) assurances that nation-states typically provide to their citizens. Other jobs of the nation-state might be eventually be challenged by other developments, but not by Bitcoin.

A successful Bitcoin is a serious competitor for people's savings. Much abuse can be prevented just by offering an exit when it is most needed.

It's one of the few trends in the world today that promise to benefit the individual and not the collective. 

That is what's at stake.

If you wonder why bitcoiners don't take your shitcoin seriously... well. That's why. 

If you're not decentralized and adversarial enough -both in ideology and technical architecture- to compete with nation-states, then you're not even playing in the same league.

If you look at what Bitcoin does, it's all basic jobs of the nation-state: 
- Protect savings
- Facilitate trade
- Bridge trust between many parties

That also explains why Bitcoin is most valuable in places where the state fails to provide these basic assurances.

I'd go deeper yet and say Bitcoin competes with nation-states, not central banks. Nation-states are the real gate-keepers of the existing financial system. Central banks exist to act in their interest.

Why I'm talking about ProgPoW, summarised in two tweets

@BlockCounter0x @sassal0x @econoar The real debate is about governance, ProgPoW is just the example at hand. I'm asking how Ethereum can resist changes from a vocal minority in the face of general voter apathy? In Bitcoin people started to run their own nodes. What will Ethereum do?
@BlockCounter0x @sassal0x @econoar I think PoS will come but it's further away than most people realize

@panekkkk @sassal0x @econoar If more people reevaluate the proposal and then it still goes through, I'm totally okay with it. 

My only agenda here is to raise awareness that a corporate takeover attempt could be taking place, not so different from NYA in Bitcoin.

@sassal0x @econoar - it's under-discussed on Twitter/Reddit relative to how fundamental the change is
- the ETH people I talk to either don't care or oppose the change
- carbon vote only had 2.5% of all ETH
- notwithstanding the above, the proposal continues marching forward

@panekkkk @sassal0x @econoar Oh yeah, I really like this argument and I wouldn't want Ethereum to change (yet). The point I'm trying to raise is how does the current approach deal with more controversial upgrades like ProgPoW where there are a few very vocal proponents, a few opponents and a lot of apathy?

@sassal0x @econoar Exactly, I meant to show that they are two different approaches. Used ProgPoW as an example why I think Bitcoin's approach is safer. If you are ProgPoW or not, would you agree that a minority can more easily push through changes without first convincing the majority?

@sassal0x @econoar I don't think it hurts the comparison because the only reason hard forks don't go through in BTC is exactly that you need overwhelming consensus - even for changes where 80% of people are indifferent about the outcome
@econoar Just a thought experiment, not to be taken at verbatim. The real world is always more complex.

Barely 2.5% of all ETH participated in the carbon-vote. Most users are simply indifferent to the change because it doesn't affect them immediately. When users vote neither with their stake nor their full nodes, a vocal minority can have a large influence on development.

@RyanSAdams Beyond the surface evidence, I like to ask "who wins from a given development?" The change would benefit GPU manufacturers and pools using specific chips that would effectively become the "new ASICs" after the change.

I don't agree that money should be centrally controlled, but we who believe that are still in the minority today. It's important to keep that in mind.

We are living in societies and national policy that doesn't have unanimous approval is not automatically coercive.

I refuse the most commonly cited counterargument against money as a social contract: "It can't be a contract because contracts by definition can't be coercive."

This view ignores that national control over monetary policy has bipartisan support in the US, and everywhere else.
The contract evolves when it doesn't fully satisfy the preferences of those involved. The emergence of cryptocurrency is a good example for that.

@spencernoon The security assumptions get even worse if we allow a foreign, liquid asset to be staked in PoS. Then neither the stake nor the block reward lose any value if the network is under attack, giving miners a de-facto carte blanche.

@spencernoon When your attack could crash the price of that asset, it is less attractive to attack in the first place. You lose that benefit if you pay miners/stakers in an asset whose value isn't tied to miners being honest.

@spencernoon If you 51% attack the network, part of your equation is getting the block reward of every block you mine (which is a lot for longer reorgs, and even more if you attack a network in perpetuity.)

Final words: Given my own and @CremeDeLaCrypto's concerns I think we might be at peak hype for Maker in relation to how much uncertainty there is around the project. Including some that might well not have any solution (decentralized oracles.)

As a result, demand to lever up cryptocurrency looks small, definitely not enough to grow dai to the levels from some of the crazier valuations I have seen. Maker can allow collateral with different trust-tradeoffs, but at the cost of sacrificing some of their own trustlessness.

In the real world, collateral is a) highly illiquid and b) retain its use value. Some examples: 1) real estate 2) inventory 3) unpaid invoices. These assets *make sense* to lever up as a business owner. Highly liquid assets? Not so much, can always just sell them instead.

4. Let's talk about collateral. MKR/dai are only as trustless as the collateral they use. The problem: tokens like ETH (or even BTC) are pretty damn useless as collateral once the novelty value is gone, and the demand to lever them up in a trustless way is quite limited.

The supply of other stablecoins is a direct function of the demand to hold them. But dai's supply is a function of demand to sell it, not to hold it, because it is created by borrowers, most of which immediately exchange it for something else.

3. In recent months, Maker has struggled to maintain their peg against the dollar (trading at a 3-4% discount). It is really hard to manage a system of their complexity to optimally match supply and demand of dai.

2. Will MKR holders act in the system's best interest? They can sell their MKR at any time so they have an incentive to maximize short term returns that shareholders of public or private companies simply don't have.
1. The oracle problem is a big question mark for me, not just for MKR but any project that requires blockchain-external data to work. Frankly, I'm not sure it *can* be solved in a decentralized way.

The absurd growth rate of the EOS blockchain shows again why networks need TX fees. When transaction costs are socialized on full nodes, demand to transact is infinite (e.g. for spam or fake activity.) The resulting blockchain bloat soon becomes a hugely centralizing force.

My article on Bitcoin's social contract polarized readers. Many found it very helpful, while others disagreed equally strongly.

In this thread I explain why I chose the term and why I think it's an effective framework for thinking about Bitcoin and cryptocurrency in general.
@mrauchs @eiaine @danheld @real_vijay @MediumSqueeze @MrHodl @brian_trollz @jack @tippin_me @CashApp Can you name any good where these steps are not mutually reinforcing / circular?
@mrauchs @eiaine @danheld @real_vijay @MediumSqueeze @MrHodl @brian_trollz @jack @tippin_me @CashApp How should I answer that? Every market participant values different things. And why circular?

@eiaine @danheld @real_vijay @MediumSqueeze @MrHodl @brian_trollz @jack @tippin_me @CashApp Cryptocurrencies work the same way. Their properties are socially emergent. We can also call it economically emergent, I don't care about that. Social choices are ultimately economic choices anyway.

That's my reasoning. I would love to get your feedback on it.

@Carsten71071425 @mrauchs @eiaine @danheld @real_vijay @MediumSqueeze @MrHodl @brian_trollz @jack @tippin_me @CashApp That's simply a part of people's preferences. Do I agree with every property of Bitcoin? No. Does that mean I would support a fork that "fixes" it? Of course not, because most of all I value the strongest social contract, being in consensus with others.

@eiaine @danheld @real_vijay @MediumSqueeze @MrHodl @brian_trollz @jack @tippin_me @CashApp Neither can someone force me to be friends with you nor can I sue you for treating me poorly. But while we both follow the social protocol, we can be friends. 

The social protocol is an emergent equilibrium. And the more people follow & enforce it, the stronger it gets.

@eiaine @danheld @real_vijay @MediumSqueeze @MrHodl @brian_trollz @jack @tippin_me @CashApp The checking creates the incentive to follow the rules voluntarily or to fall out of consensus. It's binding in the same way that we are only going to be in the same social network as long as neither of us treats the other like an asshole.

@eiaine @danheld @real_vijay @MediumSqueeze @MrHodl @brian_trollz @jack @tippin_me @CashApp A *legal* contract is recognized and enforceable by the law. In Bitcoin, users explicitly can't rely on a third party to enforce the contract for them. Instead, they check on each other.

@eiaine @danheld @real_vijay @MediumSqueeze @MrHodl @brian_trollz @jack @tippin_me @CashApp With Bitcoin, users enter a voluntary agreement that restrains them from acting in certain ways. That looks a lot like a contract. But of what kind?

@eiaine @danheld @real_vijay @MediumSqueeze @MrHodl @brian_trollz @jack @tippin_me @CashApp I don't have 1/100th your knowledge about contract law, but I'll lay out my reasons for calling it a social contract. Hope you can tell me where I went wrong.
@mrauchs @eiaine @danheld @real_vijay @MediumSqueeze @MrHodl @brian_trollz @jack @tippin_me @CashApp By determining a fair price through the forces of supply and demand?

@eiaine @danheld @real_vijay @MediumSqueeze @MrHodl @brian_trollz @jack @tippin_me @CashApp I also showed that Bitcoin's value comes from grassroots support. Only running a node and storing your own keys guarantees your Bitcoin keep the properties that make it valuable when you need them the most. Everything else is a fire insurance that shuts down the moment it burns.

@eiaine @danheld @real_vijay @MediumSqueeze @MrHodl @brian_trollz @jack @tippin_me @CashApp ETC made exchanges realize how profitable forks are for them. So they let BCH and ABC/BSV be traded as futures long in advance. Once we are past that barrier of listing them, I don't see who determines economic support for these tokens if not the market.

@eiaine @danheld @real_vijay @MediumSqueeze @MrHodl @brian_trollz @jack @tippin_me @CashApp How did they determine it, by not adding ETC right away? To me, that only proves my point because the incentive for one exchange to defect and scoop up a whole lot volume grows the more people want to trade it. Which is ultimately what happened.

@davidgerard @Carsten71071425 @Frances_Coppola @AriDavidPaul @MattSmythAudio @aleksigrym @ViliLe You just explained why the cultish elements are a feature, not a bug. You need people to obsess over the rules of the protocol and urge others to "get in line", because each cryptocurrency is only as strong as the number of people who agree on their version of the rules.

Your takeaways:
- Bitcoin rebuilds trust every block
- It needs to be expensive by design
- Trusted middlemen are amazing assets 
- Bitcoin is valuable where trust should be competitive, but isn't

As a result, Bitcoin's true value lies in making trust competitive. 

It's a protocol for hosting trust tournaments, and hence building trust from scratch between total strangers.

And that's fine because there are enough situations where middlemen cannot be trusted by definition. Why? Lack of competition.

The production of money is the prime example here. It's much harder for the market to punish a monopolist than a producer in a competitive market.
Tying it back together, if two parties already have a middleman they trust, then in practice they will always be better off using him instead of Bitcoin.

Now if the king had candidates that he already trusts (for example his family), there would be no need for a costly tournament. 

The tournament is only for situations where trust has to be built from scratch every time.

The strength of the trust is directly linked to the reward. 

This is why Bitcoin *needs* to be costly to use. (And it is also why some people are afraid Bitcoin becomes untrustworthy when rewards become smaller and smaller).

The tournament process ensures that the winner has a high degree of integrity. 

But with every tournament, people only sign up if there is a sufficient reward waiting for the winner.

Every block, Bitcoin hosts a tournament for your trust. 

For comparison, a king hosts a series of tournaments to find new members for his king's guard. New recruits are more likely to be skilled and trustworthy if they had to endure personal hardship to get the position.

This is what Bitcoin solves: Lack of competition between middlemen. You're still trusting middlemen, but Bitcoin makes the middlemen prove first that they can be trusted. 

They do that by spending money before they can make money, which binds their honesty to their profit motive

Trusted middlemen are extremely valuable. 

They only become problematic if there is no cost for misbehavior - for example, because there is no competition that keeps them in check.
Bitcoin will hardly be able to compete at transfers between people who trust each other or can have a trusted middleman. Why?

Inspired by the new JPM stablecoin, here is a short thread on 
- how Bitcoin achieves trust
- trusted middlemen
- and Bitcoin's true value

(Thread)

The takeaways:
- future life expectancy of money and other Lindy goods goes up over time, not down
- the USD might well have another 50-100 years ahead of it
- new money competes on survival, not features
- so appreciate Bitcoin's defensive developer attitude

All cryptos fight an uphill battle against established fiat currencies. And they compete less on features than you think and more on survival.

Most people will not start trusting Bitcoin's architecture. They trust their experience with it. And experience requires time.
Imagine for a moment what happens if Bitcoin died tomorrow after 10 years. It doesn't just reset the Lindy timer for all cryptocurrencies to zero. It sets it far below zero.

If you adopt the survival-is-everything model for money, I promise you will start appreciating more the careful developer attitude behind Bitcoin. 

100% improvements in efficiency might not be worth it if there is a 5% chance that it kills you in the process.

The most important thing Bitcoin has to do to become recognized as money is

survive. 

Would you trust a money to store your wealth for 10 years if it hasn't already proven to store someone else's wealth for 10 years?

A currency that is still going strong after 50 years tends to be widely recognized, distributed and integrated into our societies. In fact, it offers far more benefits than a new currency - which is why the network effects of money are so hard to break.

While increasing mortality applies to all biological or mechanical things, decreasing mortality tends to apply to the non-physical: ideas, technologies, institutions, religions, networks... the categories are overlapping but money falls squarely into several of them.

"The Lindy effect is a concept that the future life expectancy of some non-perishable things like a technology or an idea is proportional to their current age, so that every additional period of survival implies a longer remaining life expectancy." (N. Taleb)
Life expectancy decreasing proportionally to age applies to almost all living organisms, so it's an easy heuristic to over-apply. And indeed, some things are different. Enter the Lindy effect.

"The average lifespan of a currency is 50 yrs, and the USD is almost 50 years old, so..." (implying that time is running out for the dollar)

I'm seeing tweets like this a fair bit so here's a short thread on the life expectancy of money, and what that means for Bitcoin.
