3) The fund is segmented per contract, but the segments are not rolled over to the next quarter. How much money is reversed for each contract? What happens to the money when a contract expires?

Here are some more questions I would like to see answered:

1) At what size would you start calling the fund overcapitalized? Any plans on capping the fund and changing the model once that size is reached?

In summary, the post explains well why a high-leverage exchange *needs* some kind of safeguards, and if possible multiple layers of them. It gives no satisfying answers to why the BitMEX model of an internal "losers-pay-for-losers" fund is superior to existing models.

ADL means winners pay for the losers, but it also guarantees that customers will never pay more than is needed. The insurance fund means losers pay for losers, but makes them, in theory, overpay up 10x or more for the same security. The difference goes to BitMEX as profits.

So the fund is arguably too big, but that's not my main concern. It is that BitMEX itself owns the fund and not an external insurer or industry consortium. If they see the fund as what it is, an asset on their balance sheet, they are incentivized to grow it as much as possible.

"Given the volatility [in the crypto space], it‚Äôs not impossible that the fund is drained down to zero again." 

I see that as increasingly unlikely, especially considering that since the last considerable loss (in April 2018), the fund has grown from 4.8k to 21k BTC.

Better examples can be found in 2018:
16.1.2018, the fund lost 132 BTC (5% of total)
12.4.2018, the fund lost 641 BTC (13% of total)
18.7.2018, the fund lost 103 BTC (1% of total)
22.8.2018, the fund lost 155 BTC (1% of total)

So are BitMEX customers overinsured? The post gives a counterexample: In March 2017, the day the Winklevoss ETF was rejected, Bitcoin's price dropped 30% and depleted the insurance fund, causing ADL to happen. What it doesn't mention: The fund had only 66 BTC in it.

The insurance provided by the CME does explicitly NOT live on their own balance sheet. This is my big problem with the BitMEX insurance fund. CME has no incentive to overinsure their customers because they don't get to pocket excess money that is never paid out.

That difference in itself is totally fine, as the CME is a KYC exchange and also has more of an institutional audience. Losses can, in theory, be recouped via the legal system, which is hardly possible on a non-KYC exchange like BitMEX. 

However...

First, they compared the size of the fund to safeguards employed by traditional exchanges like the CME. The sum of CME's insurance is around 29% of BitMEX's insurance relative to their respective annual notional trading volumes.

Is BitMEX giving some much-needed transparency about their insurance fund?

@juliankoh @spencernoon @QWQiao I think if that was true then the staking yields would be *lower* than they should be in a fair market, not higher.

@spencernoon @QWQiao Why would ranges matter? A network that pays a higher staking yield after hedging price risk would attract more stakers until the difference is arbed. Hence we can conclude that the only reason for a network to have a higher staking yield is higher price risk.

@mikevworld @QWQiao No, but at that point, you might as well remove your native token and all the friction it brings, and replace it with something more liquid, like bitcoin or USDT. Of course, then you could no longer sell it to raise money...

@QWQiao "Does higher staking yield imply that people are bearish?" Yes, since rewards for staking are paid in-kind. Higher returns are the result of higher borrow cost - nobody wants to hold the asset.

@MrHodl @BitcoinErrorLog @nic__carter @SamouraiWallet @bergealex4 @BrickstringTech @saifedean It's the exact opposite. Under a fixed blocksize, the mempool must always be full or fees will be 0. Under a dynamic blocksize, you can target a fee rate that is deemed "secure enough" and that cost is laid across more or less users, based on demand.

@BitcoinErrorLog @MrHodl @nic__carter @SamouraiWallet @bergealex4 @BrickstringTech @saifedean Why could that be good? It introduces fees before before blocks are full, which prevents spam and greatly reduces costs put on full nodes. It also strengthens security after blockrewards have run out.

@BitcoinErrorLog @MrHodl @nic__carter @SamouraiWallet @bergealex4 @BrickstringTech @saifedean Do you realize that the blocksize in that thought experiment only adjust downwards, but never up beyond the hardcap of (currently) 2 MB? It reduces supply based on last known demand and thus drives a constant fee level.

@MrHodl @nic__carter @SamouraiWallet @bergealex4 @BrickstringTech @saifedean Are you sure that Nic's original idea of the thread, a dynamic block size with a hard cap, cannot be introduced by tightening consensus rules? Feels like it could

@parallelind Absolutely, one of the two things needs to happen until users care. Either exchanges start delisting (financial hit) or your immutability is put in question (ideological hit). So far we are seeing neither, that's my observation. But it might well change.

@nocoinerclub Exactly. Most people outside of EM are not actually worried about inflation stealing their money. You have to show them that Bitcoin solves a problem they actually understand. Many are getting deplatformed right now, so they "get" what free speech money does.

This explains why we rarely see any panic selling after 51% attacks, to date. The end users are affected neither financially (the exchange takes the hit), nor ideologically (users who value a project for their immutability don't store their money on exchanges).
To lose money from the most common 51% attacks, you either need to be an exchange or have money on an exchange that is hit so hard that you are affected as collateral.

Exchanges are the primary victim of 51% attacks. Exchanges don't list cryptocurrencies for their immutability, but to make money and apparently, the R/R pays off for them. It's *extremely* hard for a 51% attacker to target users who actually value immutability.

@libovness Mmh that's not really my problem with the token. I can imagine a case where the 0x service creates lasting value. My problem is that payment tokens add so much friction that the market will always circumvent them. The only way to prevent that is by adding even more friction.

@libovness Well, networks don't actually benefit from you running a node. Running a node is a selfish exercise, they distribute how much you need to trust any one party. I'd say networks (which are just two-sided markets for a given good) most benefit from adding to the supply/demand.
@saifedean Exactly. Insults/harassment are an attack on your limited attention span, the same way that trojans/malware etc. are an attack on your computer. Blocking is just building a firewall.

@libovness Forcing in a token and somehow "solving the pressure to circumvent it" doesn't help the user. It makes the network less valuable to users and more valuable to token creators. Hence I call working on that a zero-sum approach, as it's an exercise that cannot be mutually beneficial.

@libovness Yeah, that's certainly a prominent view in some circles (or has been). My problem with that view is that it treats the relationship between the producer and consumer as a zero-sum game. I don't see how forcing a token in there can ever benefit the consumer side.

This gotta be the nail in the coffin for payment tokens. 0x is one of the few protocols with users to begin with, and now we have the data to back up what we long assumed: the market circumvents the token any way it can.

@koeppelmann Another point on GTO in poker: GTO doesn't help you if your opponent can see your cards. Only if he can see your strategy :P So you need at least this one secret from him. And even then, you always win less than someone whose strategy is secret as well.

@koeppelmann It's way more competition. We already have institution that arbitrage trust effectively and allow cooperation: Money, markets, exchanges, property rights, the legal system... The trust you gain from a "transparent firm" cannot offset the competitive disadvantage 99% of the time.

@koeppelmann Nash equilibria in multiplayer games don't have this guarantee of neutral EV or better. Not that there were any NE for doing business. But if you want to stick with the poker example, imagine your opponents can see your cards. They can collude perfectly against you.

@eric_lombrozo Okay, I completely agree. I meant a protocol level bug that affects security of the most widely used musig script.

@eric_lombrozo No, I mean the existing Bitcoin multisig functionality based on P2SH. If there were a major bug unconvered with Bitcoin scripting, as far as I understand Bitcoin would likely hardfork to fix it (= funds safu). Whereas in Ethereum, none of the available MuSig has this assurance.

@eric_lombrozo I thought that was fascinating. In Bitcoin it's quite well defined what are the core features and that they are "insured" by the social layer. Ethereum is known to fork more liberally, but to give less assurance where it matters.

@eric_lombrozo When I looked into why Bitcoin's musig is considered more reliable than Ethereum's, part of the answer I got was if that a bug was to happen in Bitcoin's musig, users are sure it will be rolled back (protection). While Ethereum has shown it doesn't roll back for every musig bug.
@eric_lombrozo What exactly bothered you about the DAO rollback? Do you disagree with the statement "where the social layer and protocol diverge, the protocol is always wrong"?
